1-6-6: RULES OF ORDER:
The following rules of order shall in all cases be adhered to, but the same may be suspended when no objections are made, or upon a
vote of a majority of the board, except rules 4, 7 and 12.
Rule 1. The order of business at all meetings of the village board shall be established by policy adopted by the president and board of
trustees.
The order of business may be amended at any time by a majority vote of the board of trustees.
Rule 2. The president shall decide all questions of order and in all cases where these rules are not applicable, meetings of the village
board shall be governed by parliamentary law as laid down in "Robert's Rules Of Order".
Rule 3. Members discussing a question shall address the president and no member shall be deemed to have the floor until recognized
by the president.
No person except a member of the village board shall be permitted to address the same unless by the consent of the board.
Rule 4. The yeas and nays shall be taken upon the passage of all ordinances, and upon all propositions to create any liability against
the village, or for the expenditure or appropriation of its money, and in all other cases at the request of any member, which shall be
entered on the journal of the board's proceedings. The concurrence of a majority of all the members of the board of trustees shall be
necessary to the passage of any such ordinance or proposition unless otherwise provided by statute. However, at any meeting, the
board of trustees may by unanimous consent take a single vote by yeas and nays on the several questions of the passage of any two
(2) or more ordinances, orders, resolutions or motions placed together for voting purposes in a single group, which single vote shall be
entered separately in the journal under the designation "omnibus vote". In such event the clerk may enter the words "omnibus vote" in
the journal in each case in lieu of entering the names of the members of the board of trustees voting "yea" and "nay" on the passage of
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=967 53/605
each of the designated ordinances, orders, resolutions and motions included in such omnibus group.
Rule 5. All resolutions and amendments thereto shall be reduced to writing before action shall be taken thereon.
Rule 6. Standing and special committees, to whom references are made, shall in all cases report in writing the state of facts with their
opinion thereon.
Rule 7. Any report to the board of trustees shall be deferred for final action thereon, to the next regular meeting of the village board
after the report is made, upon the request of any two (2) trustees present.
Rule 8. No bill against the village shall be allowed by the board until the same has been referred to an appropriate committee for
examination unless otherwise ordered, and in all cases, receipts for money paid out and proper vouchers shall accompany each bill.
Rule 9. Every member who shall be present when a question is stated by the chair shall vote thereon, unless excused by the board, or
unless he be directly interested in the question, in which case he shall not vote.
Rule 10. When a question is before the board, no motion shall be in order but these: 1) to adjourn; 2) to lay on the table; 3) for the
previous question; 4) to postpone indefinitely; 5) to postpone to a certain time; 6) to commit; 7) to amend.
And these motions shall be privileged and have precedence in order in which they are made to succeed each other by this rule;
and motions to adjourn, to lay on the table, and for the previous questions shall be decided without debate.
Rule 11. A motion to adjourn shall always be in order except: 1) when a member is in possession of the floor, 2) when the yeas and
nays are being called, 3) when the members are voting, 4) when adjournment was the last preceding motion, 5) when it has been
decided that the previous question shall be taken; and the "previous question" shall be as follows: "Shall the main question now be
put?".
Rule 12. No vote of the board shall be reconsidered or rescinded at a special meeting unless at such special meeting there shall be
present as large a number of trustees as were present when the vote was taken.
(Ord. O2015-01, 1-20-2015)
1-6-7: ORDINANCES; APPROVAL, VETO:
A. All resolutions and motions: 1) which create any liability against the village, or 2) which provide for the expenditure or appropriation
of money, or 3) which authorize the sale of any village property and all ordinances passed by the board of trustees shall be decided
by a roll call vote or by omnibus vote, as permitted by statute, and all ordinances and resolutions passed by the village board shall
be deposited with the village clerk.
B. If the village president approves of any ordinance, resolution or motion specified in subsection A of this section, he shall sign them.
Those of which he disapproves, he shall return to the board of trustees, with his written objections, at the next regular meeting of
the board of trustees occurring not less than five (5) days after their passage. The village president may disapprove of any one or
more sums appropriated in any ordinance, resolution or motion making an appropriation, and if so, the remainder shall be effective.
However, the village president may disapprove entirely of an ordinance, resolution or motion making an appropriation.
C. If the village president fails to return an ordinance or any specified resolution with his written objections, within the designated time,
it shall become effective despite the absence of his signature.
D. Every resolution and motion specified in this section, and every ordinance, which is returned to the board of trustees by the village
president shall be reconsidered by the board of trustees at the next regular meeting. If, after such reconsideration, two-thirds (2/3)
of all the trustees then holding office shall agree at such regular meeting to pass an ordinance, resolution or motion,
notwithstanding the president's refusal to approve it, then it shall be effective. The vote on the question of passage over the
president's veto shall be by yeas and nays, and shall be recorded in the journal. (Ord., 2-2-1988)
Chapter 7
VILLAGE CLERK
1-7-1: APPOINTMENT; TERM; SALARY:
The village clerk shall be appointed by the village president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees and serve for a four
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=967 54/605
(4) year term and until his or her successor is appointed and qualified, as provided by law1. The salary for the village clerk shall be set
by ordinance or resolution as provided in section 1-8-7 of this title, as amended. (Ord. O2011-20, 5-3-2011)
1-7-2: BOND:
(Rep. by Ord. O2002-27, 5-7-2002)
1-7-3: GENERAL POWERS AND DUTIES:
The village clerk shall have all the powers and perform all the duties now or hereafter provided by the laws of the state and the
ordinances of the village.
A. Duties: Among other things, it shall be his duty as follows:
1. To keep his office at the place appointed by the board of trustees;
2. To attend all meetings of the board of trustees and to take minutes of all its proceedings, including executive session meetings
as provided by section 3.1-35-90 of the Illinois municipal code, 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3.1-35-90, as amended;
3. To record such minutes, together with all ordinances passed by the board of trustees, in books to be kept for that purpose;
4. To publish all proceedings of the board of trustees and all ordinances required by law to be published;
5. To serve all notices, either by personal service, by publication or by posting, required by law or the order of the board of trustees
or the president to be served, unless such notices are expressly ordered to be served by some other person;
6. To sign and keep a record of all warrants drawn on the village treasurer, stating the date, number and amount thereof, to whom
payable and against what fund drawn;
7. To perform all of the duties pertaining to the conduct of village elections as provided by state law;
8. To notify, within five (5) days after the result of any election is declared or appointment made, all persons elected or appointed to
any village office of their election or appointment, and unless such persons shall respectively qualify within ten (10) days after
such notice, the office shall become vacant;
9. To file all ordinances, communications, receipts and other documents required to be filed, and to arrange the same in systematic
order for ready reference;
10. To keep the corporate seal of the village and affix the same to all papers which require it;
11. To be the custodian and keeper of all the books, records, ordinances and papers of the village, except as otherwise provided by
law or ordinance;
12. To make copies of all papers in his office, and transcripts from journals and other records and files of his office, certified under
the corporate seal for use in evidence when required; and
13. To file or cause to be filed a certified copy of each tax levy ordinance with the county clerk of DuPage County and the county
clerk of Cook County within the time required by law. (Ord. O2011-20, 5-3-2011)
B. Documents: The village clerk shall be the custodian of all documents belonging to the village which are not assigned to the custody
of some other officer. (1965 Code § 3-1.04)
C. Indexes: The village clerk shall keep and maintain a proper index to all documents and records kept by him, so that ready access
thereto and use thereof may be had. (1965 Code § 3-1.05)
D. Additional Duties: In addition to the duties herein provided, the village clerk shall perform such other duties and functions as may be
required by statute or ordinance. (1965 Code § 3-1.06)
1-7-4: VACANCIES:
In the case the office of village clerk shall become vacant for any reason, the president shall appoint a successor to fill such office with
the advice and consent of the board of trustees as provided by statute. The president and board of trustees may appoint a village clerk
pro tempore whenever necessary, as provided by statute. (Ord. O2011-20, 5-3-2011)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=967 55/605
1-7-5: DEPUTY CLERK:
A. Authorization; Appointment: The president and board of trustees may authorize the village clerk to appoint or designate one deputy
clerk. After such authorization, the village clerk may appoint or designate such a deputy clerk, with the advice and consent of the
president and board of trustees. The deputy clerk shall serve at the will of the president and board of trustees.
B. Powers And Duties: The deputy clerk shall have the powers and duties to execute all documents required by any law to be
executed by the village clerk and to affix the seal of the village clerk to such documents wherever required. In signing any
document, the deputy clerk shall sign the name of the village clerk followed with the word "By" and the deputy clerk's own name
and the words "Deputy Clerk".
The deputy clerk also shall have the authority to execute the powers and duties of the village clerk in the absence of the village
clerk or when the president and board of trustees have determined by resolution that the village clerk is temporarily or permanently
incapacitated to perform such powers and duties. (Ord., 12-15-1992)
1-7-6: ASSISTANT CLERKS:
The president and board of trustees may authorize the village clerk to appoint or designate one or more assistant clerks to aid in
carrying out the functions of the office of village clerk. After such authorization, the village clerk may appoint or designate such an
assistant or assistants, with the advice and consent of the president and board of trustees. Assistant clerks shall serve at the will of the
president and board of trustees. (Ord., 12-15-1992)
Chapter 8
VILLAGE OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES
1-8-1: APPLICATION OF REGULATIONS:
The provisions of this chapter shall apply alike to all officers, or employees of the village, regardless of the time of the creation of the
office or of the time of the appointment of the officer. (1965 Code, sec. 9-1.01)
1-8-2: APPOINTMENTS:
The village manager, the village attorney, and the village treasurer shall be appointed by the village president with the approval of the
board of trustees. The fire chief and police chief shall be appointed by the village president and confirmed by the board of trustees
upon the recommendation of the village manager. All members of the village boards and commissions shall be appointed by the village
president with approval of a majority of the board of trustees, except as otherwise provided by statute. All other employees shall, in the
absence of any provision of state law or this code to the contrary, be hired by the village manager. (Ord., 12-16-1991)
1-8-3: TERMS OF OFFICE; VACANCIES:
Every salaried appointive officer of the village shall hold office until terminated by the appointing official. Vacancies shall be filled in the
same manner in which appointments are made unless otherwise provided by ordinance or statute.
Elected village officers shall be inaugurated at the first regular meeting of the board of trustees in May of odd numbered years.
Every officer and employee of the village, upon expiration of his term for any cause whatsoever, shall deliver to his successor all books
and records which may be the property of the village, and if no successor has been appointed within one week after the termination of
office, such property shall be delivered to the village manager or his designee. (Ord., 12-7-1982)
1-8-4: OATH:
Every officer of the village shall, before entering upon his duties, take the oath prescribed by law, as follows1:
I do solemnly swear (or affirm as the case may be) that I will support the Constitution of the United States and the Constitution of the
State of Illinois, and that I will faithfully discharge the duties of the office of according to the best of my ability,
which oath, or affirmation, so subscribed shall be filed in the office of the village clerk. (1965 Code, sec. 9-1.07)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=967 56/605
1-8-5: OFFICERS AND OFFICIALS BONDS:
The board of trustees shall secure and maintain at the village's expense, a bond or bonds for all officers and officials of the village for
which such a bond is required by state law or by declaration of the board of trustees. Such bond or bonds shall be conditioned on the
faithful performance of the duties of such officers and officials. Such bond or bonds shall be in an amount not less than provided by
state law and shall be maintained in accordance with the standards of state law. (Ord. O2002-27, 5-7-2002)
1-8-6: FAILURE TO QUALIFY:
No officer shall be commissioned until he has given his bond, and if he does not take the oath or affirmation and present said bond to
the village clerk within ten (10) days after notification by the clerk of his election or appointment, his office shall become vacant. If the
village clerk does not file his bond within thirty (30) days after his election, his office shall thereupon become vacant. (1965 Code, sec.
9-1.15)
1-8-7: SALARIES:
All officers and employees of the village shall receive such salaries as may be provided from time to time by ordinance or resolution.
(1965 Code, sec. 9-1.09)
1-8-8: ASSIGNMENT OF DUTIES:
The village manager shall have the power to assign to any appointive officer any duty which is not assigned by ordinance to some
other specific officer; and shall determine disputes or questions relating to the respective powers or duties of office. (1965 Code, sec.
9-1.05)
1-8-9: RECORDS:
All records kept by any officer of the village shall be open to inspection by the village president, or any member of the board of trustees
at all reasonable times, whether or not such records are required to be kept by statute or ordinance. (1965 Code, sec. 9-1.06)
1-8-10: DISPOSITION OF MONIES RECEIVED:
Every officer of the village shall at least once each month turn over all money received by him in his official capacity, to the village
treasurer with a statement showing the source from which the same is received. (1965 Code, sec. 9-1.04)
1-8-11: CONSERVATORS OF THE PEACE DESIGNATED:
The village president, the members of the board of trustees, the village manager, the director of public services, the superintendent of
public works, the building commissioner, the village attorney, the superintendent of streets, the plumbing inspector, the electrical
inspector, members of the fire department, as well as every member of the police department, are hereby declared to be conservators
of the peace with such powers to make arrests as are given to conservators of the peace by statute2. (1965 Code, sec. 9-1.10)
1-8-12: OFFICE HOURS:
The offices of the respective village officers shall be open for business on such days and between such hours as the board of trustees
shall from time to time prescribe. (1965 Code, sec. 9-1.14)
1-8-13: OFFICER AND OFFICIAL INDEMNIFICATION AND DEFENSE:
A. Findings: This board of trustees finds that it is the public policy of this state that officers and officials of government bodies shall not
be liable in damages for the exercise of discretion in determining policies. This public policy is set forth in 745 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 10/2-201, which provides:
Except as otherwise provided by statute, a public employee serving in a position involving the determination of policy or the
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=967 57/605
exercise of discretion is not liable for an injury resulting from his act or omission in determining policy when acting in the exercise of
such discretion even though abused.
B. Indemnification And Defense: To the extent that any claim or action is brought against any current or former trustee, commissioner,
board member, or officer of the village that is based upon any act, error, or omission that could reasonably be construed to be
within the exercise of that person's lawful duties and that is not covered by insurance maintained by the village, the village, subject
to the provisions of subsection D of this section, shall undertake the following:
1. To appear and defend that person against any such claim or action, whether civil, criminal or administrative in nature; and
2. To indemnify and hold harmless that person from any judgment, fine, liability or other cost related to such claim or action,
including any compromise or settlement costs of such claim or action.
C. Rights Nonexclusive: The foregoing rights shall not be exclusive of any rights that any current or former trustee, commissioner,
board member or officer of the village may have as a matter of law. In the case of the death of such trustee, commissioner, board
member or officer, the foregoing rights shall inure to the benefit of his or her successors.
D. Exception: This section shall not apply to provide any defense or indemnification to any current or former trustee, commissioner,
board member or officer in any investigation, claim, action or proceeding instituted by the village against such trustee,
commissioner, board member or officer. (Ord., 7-6-1989)
ARTICLE A. VILLAGE MANAGER
1-8A-1: CREATION OF OFFICE, APPOINTMENT:
There is hereby created the office of village manager, a position of employment with the village. The village manager shall be
appointed by the village president and board of trustees for an indefinite term as provided by law. (1965 Code, sec. 4-1.01)
1-8A-2: QUALIFICATIONS AND REMOVAL:
A. The village manager shall be chosen on the basis of his or her executive and administrative qualifications and technical knowledge,
training and experience of and in the duties of the office of village manager. The village manager shall have advanced,
postgraduate education in public administration or other area of study relevant to the duties of the office of village manager.
B. The village manager shall reside in the village, or within a reasonable distance of the village subject to the approval of the president
and board of trustees. Under no circumstances shall the village manager reside at such a distance from the village that the faithful
and proper performance of his or her duties is impaired.
C. The employment of the village manager shall be at the will and desire of the president and board of trustees, who, voting jointly,
may terminate such employment at any time without cause. No term of appointment or employment as village manager shall be
construed as creating any property or other right to a continuation of that appointment or employment.
D. During the absence or disability for any reason of the village manager, the village president, with the approval of the board of
trustees, may designate some properly qualified person to perform the duties of the position of village manager. (Ord., 11-21-1989)
1-8A-3: COMPENSATION:
The village manager shall receive such compensation as shall be fixed from time to time by the president and board of trustees. (1965
Code, sec. 4-1.03)
1-8A-4: POWERS AND DUTIES:
A. General:
1. The village manager shall have and exercise all powers and duties assigned to him by statute and such other authority as may
be granted by the president and board of trustees. He shall be charged with the enforcement of all laws and ordinances within
the municipality insofar as their enforcement is within the powers of the village.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=967 58/605
2. The village manager shall attend all meetings of the president and board of trustees; shall keep the president and board of
trustees informed as to the affairs of the village, and shall recommend to the president and board of trustees such actions as may
be necessary or expedient for the welfare of the village. (1965 Code, sec. 4-1.04)
B. Employees: The village manager shall hire and discharge the employees (other than those under the board of fire and police
commissioners or other tenure of office laws) so authorized by the president and board of trustees, to be hired at such
compensation as may be set or authorized by the president and board of trustees. All such employees shall perform their duties
subject to whom the manager may assign such employee. Provided, that the village manager may delegate to any other official or
employee the authority to hire or discharge any employee so authorized. (1965 Code, sec. 4-1.05)
C. Appointments: The following positions in the village shall be filled by appointment of the village manager: the director of finance; the
director of public services; the superintendent of public works; the superintendent of streets; the building commissioner; the
electrical inspector; and the plumbing inspector. The village manager shall report any appointment, or any removal, to the president
and board of trustees as soon as possible after such appointment or removal. (Ord., 11-3-1987)
D. Departments: All administrative departments of the village shall be under the supervision and control of the village manager,
including the police department, the fire department, the municipal utilities, the department of public works, the building department,
the humane officer and the general office of the village. The village manager shall have the power to remove from office any officer
appointed by him. (1965 Code § 4-1.07)
E. Contracts:
1. The village manager shall examine all proposed contracts to which the village may be a party, may make or enter into such
contracts or procurements on behalf of the village as authorized in section 1-11-4 of this title, and may sign on behalf of the
village any contract authorized by the president and board of trustees, excepting where the president and board of trustees direct
that some other officer or officers shall do so.
It shall be the duty of the village manager to see to it that all terms of any contract to which the village is a party are fully
performed by all parties thereto. (Ord., 2-2-1988)
2. The village manager shall not be financially interested directly or indirectly in any contract, work or business of the village or in
the sale of any article to the village or in purchase of any property belonging to the village or sold for taxes or assessments or
sold by virtue of legal process at the suit of the village. (1965 Code § 4-1.09)
F. Purchases: The village manager shall create, implement and administer a village of Hinsdale purchasing policy manual. Any
amendments or revisions to the purchasing policy manual after its initial approval and adoption shall be communicated by the
village manager to the president and board of trustees. The village manager shall be the general purchasing agent of the village,
and except where specific provision to the contrary is made by statute, or by the president and board of trustees, he or she shall
make all purchases of supplies, materials and equipment authorized by the president and board of trustees in the manner
prescribed by, and subject to the limitations imposed by, law and by the purchasing policy manual. No purchase shall be made or
obligation incurred except as authorized by section 1-11-4 of this title or as otherwise authorized by the president and board of
trustees, and no expenses shall be incurred except for the purpose for which no prior appropriation is required by law, if the amount
thereof is not covered by an unexpended appropriation for the purpose. (Ord. O2014-18, 5-20-2014)
G. Appropriation And Levies: It shall be the duty of the manager to prepare or to cause to be prepared each year a budget and the
annual appropriation ordinance in time for consideration and enactment by the village president and board of trustees during the
first quarter of the fiscal year; and to prepare the tax levy ordinance for passage.
He shall keep or cause to be kept, current accounts of the amounts appropriated and the amounts showing at all times the fiscal
condition of the village, including the current and anticipated expenses, appropriations, cash on hand and anticipated revenue of all
municipal funds and accounts. He shall see to the collection of all money due the village. (1965 Code § 4-1.11)
H. Inventories, Property: The village manager shall keep or cause to be kept a current inventory showing all real and personal property
of the village and the location of such property, and shall be responsible for the care and custody of all such property including
equipment, buildings, parks and all such property which is not by law assigned to some other officer or body for care and control.
(1965 Code § 4-1.13)
I. Records, Certificates: The village manager shall prepare and have custody of all municipal records required by law to be kept by the
village and not by a specific officer. Where the law makes it the duty of a specific officer to keep or maintain records, the village
manager shall make available to such officer all necessary clerical assistance for the preparation of such records and shall make
available a place for the custody of such records. In compliance herewith, the village manager shall make available to the clerk,
stenographic or clerical assistance necessary for the preparation of the journal of village board proceedings, and the record of
ordinances and all other documents which by law the clerk is required to keep; and he shall perform similar service for the treasurer
in the maintenance of bond registers, and all other records or documents which by law the treasurer is required to keep or prepare.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=967 59/605
When the law requires or provides for certification of any records or documents by any officer of the village, the village manager
shall require such records or documents to be properly prepared and presented to such officer for his signature. (1965 Code § 4-
1.13)
J. Maps, Plats: The village manager shall cause to be kept a complete set of maps and plats showing the location of all village utilities,
and other municipal properties, all streets and other public places and all lots or parcels of land subdivided according to law. (1965
Code § 4-1.14)
1-8A-5: OFFICES:
The village manager shall maintain an office in the village hall and shall spend such time in the performance of his duties as may be
required by the president and board of trustees. (1965 Code § 4-1.15)
1-8A-6: ANNUAL REPORT:
The manager shall prepare and present to the president and board of trustees, a written report summarizing the activities of each
department, office or operation of the village, including appropriate financial information. (1965 Code § 4-1.16)
1-8A-7: ADDITIONAL DUTIES:
He shall, from time to time, make recommendations to the president and the board of trustees or the appropriate committee thereof
relative to the adoption of such ordinances and resolutions as he may deem necessary or expedient.
He shall, from time to time, make reports or recommendations to the president and board of trustees or the appropriate committee
thereof relative to the affairs of the village, as he may deem advisable or the president and board of trustees or appropriate committee
thereof may request.
He shall render to the several officers of the village, and said officers shall render to him, all such assistance as is possible in the
performance of their respective duties, and all officers and employees of the village shall furnish and disclose to him such oral or
written information and material relating to the affairs of the village as he shall request. (1965 Code § 4-1.17)
1-8A-8: SUBJECT TO POWERS OF VILLAGE PRESIDENT AND BOARD OF TRUSTEES:
All functions, powers and duties hereby conferred or imposed upon the village manager shall be subject to the superior right and
power of the village president and board of trustees to supervise and administer the government and affairs of the village. However, all
acts and things done by the village manager pursuant to this chapter shall, unless in this chapter otherwise expressly provided, be final
and conclusive unless and until superseded by the action of the village president or board of trustees. (1965 Code § 4-1.18)
ARTICLE B. VILLAGE ATTORNEY
1-8B-1: LEGAL COUNSEL:
Legal counsel shall be retained by the president and board of trustees to advise the village on legal matters, to prosecute and defend
legal actions, and draft legal documents and furnish opinions. Said counsel shall be retained from time to time at the will of the
president and board of trustees for such compensation as they shall determine. (Ord., 11-2-1965)
ARTICLE C. VILLAGE TREASURER
1-8C-1: CREATION OF OFFICE; APPOINTMENT:
There is hereby created the office of village treasurer. The treasurer shall be appointed by the president, by and with the advice and
consent of the board of trustees. (Ord., 11-3-1987)
1-8C-2: BOND:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=967 60/605
(Rep. by Ord. O2002-27, 5-7-2002)
1-8C-3: GENERAL POWERS AND DUTIES:
The village treasurer shall be responsible to the board of trustees but under the supervision of the village manager. He shall have the
power and perform the duties provided by statute and by the ordinances of the village. Among other things, it shall be his duty as
follows:
A. To receive all monies due or belonging to the village and pay all orders or warrants, including special assessment and other bonds
and interest coupons, authorized by the board of trustees and duly executed by the proper officers of the village.
B. To keep, or cause to be kept, suitable books of account, showing in a simple and methodical manner all monies received by him,
and from whom and on what account or fund they have been received, and all monies paid out by him, to whom and on what
account or fund paid, and for what purpose. The books shall be balanced by him monthly.
C. To keep, or cause to be kept, a separate account with each fund or appropriation stating at the head of each account the amount to
be appropriated and giving the several debits and credits belonging thereto.
D. To keep, or cause to be kept, an account with each special assessment, under its general description and number, giving in detail
all receipts and disbursements therein.
E. To make a monthly report of his transactions as treasurer to the president and board of trustees, which report shall be filed with said
board together with canceled vouchers covering all transactions embraced in said report.
F. To annually, within thirty (30) days of the end of the fiscal year, make out and file with the village clerk a full and detailed account of
all his receipts and disbursements as such treasurer during the preceding fiscal year of the village, which account shall show the
state of the treasury at the close of the fiscal year. A copy of such report, as filed with the village clerk and bearing the affidavit
thereof, together with a copy of the published report, shall be filed with the county collector before September 1 as required by
statute1. (1965 Code, sec. 4-3.04)
1-8C-4: DEPOSIT AND INVESTMENT OF FUNDS:
The treasurer shall deposit the village funds in such depositories as may be determined by the board of trustees as provided by law;
the deposit of village money shall be kept separate and distinct from the treasurer's funds and the treasurer shall not make any private
or personal use of any village money.
The treasurer may invest public funds as permitted by 30 Illinois Compiled Statutes 235/2, as supplemented. No such investments
shall be made contrary to the specific provisions of any other statute, including pension statutes or any ordinance of the village,
including the provisions of revenue bond ordinances. (Ord., 11-5-1980)
1-8C-5: SPECIAL ASSESSMENT FUNDS:
All monies received on any special assessment shall be held by the treasurer as a special fund to be applied only to the payment of
the improvement, or bonds and vouchers issued therefor, together with interest thereon, for which the assessment was made, and said
money shall be used for no other purpose, unless to reimburse the village for the money expended for such improvement. Payments
on bonds or vouchers shall be made in accordance with the statutes, and the treasurer shall keep his books and accounts in such a
manner so that proper prorations in payments of principal and interest can be made and ascertained. (1965 Code, sec. 4-3.06)
1-8C-6: WARRANTS; TRANSFER OF FUNDS:
All warrants drawn on the treasurer must be signed by the village president and countersigned by the village clerk, stating the
particular fund or appropriations to which the same is chargeable, and the person to whom payable; and no money shall be otherwise
paid except as may be provided by statute. Money shall not be transferred by the treasurer from one fund to another, after it has been
received by him, nor appropriated to any other purpose other than that for which it has been collected or paid, except as may be
ordered by the village president and board of trustees in manner and form prescribed by statute. (1965 Code, sec. 4-3.07)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=967 61/605
1-8C-7: ASSISTANT VILLAGE TREASURER:
A. Creation Of Position; Appointment: The president and board of trustees, voting jointly, may authorize the treasurer to appoint an
assistant village treasurer. The treasurer, upon such authorization, shall appoint the assistant treasurer, with the approval of the
president and board of trustees.
B. Compensation: The assistant treasurer shall serve without compensation.
C. Bond: The assistant treasurer shall furnish a surety bond, conditioned on the faithful performance of his or her duties and in such
sum as the board of trustees shall prescribe, with the premium for such bond to be paid by the village.
D. Duties: The assistant treasurer shall perform such duties as the treasurer may from time to time delegate and direct. (Ord., 11-3-
1987)
ARTICLE D. VILLAGE DIRECTOR OF FINANCE
1-8D-1: CREATION OF POSITION; APPOINTMENT:
There is hereby created the position of village director of finance, a position of employment with the village. The director of finance
shall be appointed by the village manager. (1965 Code, sec. 4-3.04)
1-8D-2: QUALIFICATIONS:
The director of finance shall be chosen on the basis of his or her technical training and knowledge in the fields of municipal finances,
budgeting, and accounting, and on his or her expertise and experience in the duties and responsibilities of the office of director of
finance. (Ord. O2002-27, 5-7-2002)
1-8D-3: COMPENSATION:
The director of finance shall receive such compensation as shall be fixed from time to time by the president and board of trustees.
(Ord., 11-3-1987)
1-8D-4: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The director of finance shall perform such duties and shall have such responsibilities as delegated and directed by the village
manager. Said duties and responsibilities shall include:
A. To supervise the accounting work of the village and to be responsible for all duties and responsibilities of the position of director of
finance.
B. To assist the village manager in preparing and presenting to the board of trustees at the end of each fiscal year a budget estimate of
revenue and expenditure for the ensuing year.
C. To assist the village manager in preparing and presenting to the board of trustees on or before the first meeting in July of each year
a draft of an appropriation ordinance appropriating such sum or sums of money as may be deemed necessary to defray all
necessary expenses and liabilities of the village, specifying particularly the object and purposes for which such appropriations are
made and the amount appropriated for each object or purpose.
D. To execute all warrants for special assessments and other warrants which by law and the ordinances of the village may be directed
to him or her.
E. To make a return of all special assessment warrants and a report in writing of all delinquent lists of special assessments and special
taxes to such officer as may be designated by statute, which return and report shall be made at the time or times and in the manner
provided by law.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=967 62/605
F. To file with the village clerk, between May 1 and May 10 of each year, a statement of: 1) all the money collected by him or her during
the year, 2) the particular warrant, special assessment, or account on which such money was collected, 3) the balance of money
uncollected on all warrants in his or her possession, and 4) the balance remaining uncollected at the time of the return on all
warrants which he or she returned to the village clerk during the preceding fiscal year.
G. To collect all water, sewer, garbage, and other charges and all license fees for any and all licenses issued under the ordinances of
the village, together with all permit fees and other monies due to the village, the collection of which is not by law or ordinance
provided to be made by some other officer of the village.
H. To keep an accurate record of all bonds, notes, and other obligations issued by or payable to the village, with the date thereof, the
person to whom or by whom payable, the rate of interest, and such other particulars as may be necessary for a full understanding
thereof.
I. To keep his or her books and accounts in such manner as the village manager may prescribe. Such warrants, books, and papers
pertaining to his or her office shall be open to the inspection of and subject to the examination of the president, the village clerk, the
board of trustees, and the village manager at all times.
J. To deposit daily to the credit of the village treasurer in such depository as the president and board of trustees shall by ordinance
designate, all monies collected by him or her from any source whatever, taking a receipt therefor. (Ord., 11-3-1987)
ARTICLE E. COORDINATOR OF FEDERAL AND STATE AID
1-8E-1: CREATION OF OFFICE:
There is created the office of Coordinator of Federal and State Aid pursuant to the provisions of chapter 24, section 11-5.1-1 of the
Illinois Municipal Code. The Coordinator is to be appointed by the Village President by and with the advice and consent of the Board of
Trustees.
1-8E-2: DUTIES:
The duties of the Coordinator are to advise the Village President and Board of Trustees and the Village Manager of objects and
programs for which State and Federal funds are or may be available and to assist in obtaining said funds for objects and programs of
the Village which have been approved by the President and Board of Trustees. (2-6-73)
Chapter 9
DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC SERVICES

There is hereby created the Department of Public Services which shall be under the jurisdiction of the Village Manager. (1965 Code,
sec. 5-1.01)
1-9-2: MEMBERS; APPOINTMENT:
This Department shall consist of the Director of Public Services, Superintendent of Public Works; the Superintendent of Streets; the
Building Commissioner; the Plumbing Inspector, and the Electrical Inspector. Such members shall be appointed by the Village
Manager. (1965 Code, sec. 5-1.02)
1-9-3: SUPERVISION OF DEPARTMENT:
The Director of Public Services, subject to orders of the Village Manager, shall supervise all work and employees connected with or
assigned to such Department. (1965 Code, sec. 5-1.03)

ARTICLE A. DIRECTOR OF PUBLIC SERVICES
1-9A-1: CREATION OF OFFICE, SUPERVISION:
There is hereby created the post of Director of Public Services, a position of employment in the Village,to administer, coordinate, train,
direct and supervise the Public Works Department,water utility, and the Building and Inspectional Services Department. (1965 Code,
sec. 5-2.01)
The Director of Public Services shall be responsible to the Village Manager for the performance of the duties as outlined hereafter and
such other duties as may be assigned from time to time. (1965 Code, sec. 5-2.04)
1-9A-2: APPOINTMENT AND REMOVAL:
The Director of Public Services shall be appointed by the Village Manager and shall serve for an indefinite term. He shall be chosen
solely on the basis of his executive and administrative qualifications, with special reference to his actual experience in and knowledge
of accepted practice in respect to the duties of his office herein set forth. He may be removed at any time by the Village Manager for
cause. (1965 Code, sec. 5-2.02)
1-9A-3: COMPENSATION:
The Director of Public Services shall receive such compensation as shall be fixed from time to time by the President and Board of
Trustees. (1965 Code, sec. 5-2.03)
1-9A-4: GENERAL POWERS AND DUTIES:
The specific duties of the Director of Public Services shall include but not be limited to the following:
A. The administration, direction and supervision of the Public Works, Water, Building and Inspectional Services Departments.
B. The organization, development and coordination of work programs.
C. The preparation of budget requests, recommendations and justifications.
D. The preparation of bid specifications. The definition and periodic appraisal of service needs.
E. The supervision of capital improvements.
F. The provision of independent inspectional services.
G. The preparation of long-range plans, reports, programs and studies, to effect economy in service costs and/or to improve service.
H. To aid in the recruitment, selection and appointment of qualified personnel to fill such openings or vacancies as may occur.
I. To submit an annual report for each of the departments and such other reports as may be required.
J. To increase by training and education the knowledge, competence and ability of personnel in the Public Works, Water and Building
Departments.
K. To develop both short and long-range departmental plans and objectives. (1965 Code, sec. 5-2.05)
1-9A-5: ADDITIONAL DUTIES:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=967 64/605
The Director of Public Services shall also have the following additional duties:
A. To serve as secretary to the Hinsdale Utilities Commission.
B. Such other duties as may be assigned from time to time by the Village Manager. (1965 Code, sec. 5-2.06; amd. 1-16-73)
ARTICLE B. SUPERINTENDENT OF PUBLIC WORKS
1-9B-1: POSITION CREATED:
There is hereby created the position of Superintendent of Public Works, a position of employment of the Village. The Superintendent of
Public Works shall be selected and appointed by the Village Manager. (1965 Code, sec. 5-3.01)
1-9B-2: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The Superintendent of Public Works shall be the head of the Department of Public Works, He shall have the general management and
supervision under the Director of Public Services over all matters pertaining to said Department, and shall have the powers and
perform the duties provided by law and by ordinances of the Village. Among other things, he shall have the following powers and
perform the following duties:
A. To have charge of all public improvements in the Village. Subject to the ordinances of the Village, the Superintendent of Public
Works shall regulate and control the construction, maintenance, repair and the manner of using the streets, alleys, highways,
sidewalks, sewers, culverts, drains and all public grounds, places and buildings of the Village, regulate and supervise the
construction, maintenance and repair of all sewers, drains, culverts and public places whenever the same are installed in any public
street or other public place, are taken up or altered, and regulate the construction, maintenance and repair of water, gas or steam
pipes, or other pipes or conduits within the right of way of any public street or alley or within any public ground.
B. To cause the prompt repair of the streets, alleys, highways, sidewalks, sewers, drains, culverts and public places whenever the
same are taken up or altered; and have charge of the removal and disposal of garbage and other household wastes.
C. To prescribe the mode of piercing or opening any of the sewers or drains, and the form, size and material of the connections made
therewith, except as otherwise provided by ordinance, and to have authority to grant permission to make lateral connections with
said sewers and drains.
D. To regulate the laying down of gas, water or steam pipes, and the erection and location of telegraph and telephone poles and other
poles or posts within the limits of any public street, alley or other public ground, and to determine their location therein; all subject to
the direction of the Village Manager.
E. To have general supervision over all surveying done for the Village and over the laying out and the establishment of lines and
grades of streets, alleys, sidewalks, sewers, drains, culverts, and other public improvements under his supervision, and to have
charge of the engineering work in connection with such public improvements undertaken by the Village.
F. To issue all permits to connect house drains and private sewers with the public sewers of the Village, and to superintend the
construction of such private drains and sewers.
G. To make all estimates for payment on contracts as the work under his supervision progresses, and as may be required under the
ordinances, specifications and contracts.
H. To make, prepare and submit all necessary plans, maps, plats, profiles, specifications, or estimates for any public work or
improvement under his supervision which may be proposed or ordered by the Board of Trustees, or required by the Village Attorney
or Board of Local Improvements.
I. To carefully preserve in his office all engineering field notes, maps, plans, profiles, papers, books, writings and records made by him
or pertaining to his office, and to arrange and index the same in such a manner that a ready reference may be had thereto.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=967 65/605
J. To have special charge of all maps, plats, atlases, charts, surveys and records pertaining to the sewerage and drainage systems of
the Village, to the public streets, alleys, sidewalks, culverts, and all public places of the Village, and to the house numbering system
of the Village.
K. To obtain and keep in his office a complete atlas of all sewers, water mains, electric lines, gas mains and other public service
facilities, laid or constructed in the Village, with all junctions, house connections and other appurtenances distinctly recorded
therein.
L. To keep a systematic record of all transactions within the Department, and to record, in a suitable book to be provided by the Village,
all grades and bench marks established by the Board of Trustees, and all such books, records and files shall be the exclusive
property of the Village.
M. To superintend the preservation, culture and planting of shade and ornamental trees, plants and shrubbery in the parkways and in
parks and playgrounds and other public places; to direct the pruning, trimming, spraying, cultivating and otherwise maintaining of
such trees, shrubs and plants; to advise owners and occupants of lots regarding the kind of trees, plants and shrubbery, and the
method of planting best adapted to, or most desirable on particular streets, and to take such measures as may be deemed
necessary for the control and extermination of insects and other pests and plant diseases which may injuriously affect trees, plants
or shrubs that are now growing or may be hereafter growing in the parkways, parks or playgrounds and public places in the Village.
N. Said Superintendent shall render a written report monthly to the Village Manager covering the work of his Department and showing
the work performed, and actual or estimated cost thereof, and such other information as may be requested by the Village President,
Village Manager or Board of Trustees, and shall annually within thirty (30) days after the close of the fiscal year of the Village,
render a written report to the Village Manager covering the work of his Department during the previous fiscal year. (1965 Code, sec.
5-3.02)
ARTICLE C. SUPERINTENDENT OF STREETS
1-9C-1: POSITION CREATED:
There is hereby created the position of Superintendent of Streets, a position of employment of the Village. The Superintendent of
Streets shall be appointed by the Village Manager. (1965 Code, sec. 5-4.01)
1-9C-2: GENERAL POWERS AND DUTIES:
The Superintendent of Streets shall perform his duties under the immediate direction of the Village Manager and the Director of Public
Services, and he shall perform all duties required of him by the ordinances of the Village and such other duties as may be required of
him by the Director of Public Services or the Village Manager. Among other things, he may be required to perform the following duties:
A. To superintend the prompt repairing of streets, alleys, highways and public places whenever such repairing shall become necessary.
He shall have special charge and superintendence of all streets, alleys, lanes and highways of the Village, and of all walks and
crosswalks, subject to the direction and control of the Director of Public Services.
B. To have charge of all sewers and drains in any of the streets, alleys or public places in the Village, and shall keep the same in good
order and condition, and clean and free from obstruction, and shall cause to be made such repairs thereof, and of the receiving
basin, culverts and openings connected therewith as may from time to time become necessary, or as may be ordered by the
Director of Public Services. (1965 Code, sec. 5-4.02)
ARTICLE D. BUILDING COMMISSIONER
1-9D-1: APPOINTMENT:
There is hereby created the position of Building Commissioner, who shall be appointed by the Village Manager. (1965 Code, sec. 5-
5.01)
1-9D-2: GENERAL POWERS AND DUTIES:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=967 66/605
A. Enforcement: It shall be the duty of the Building Commissioner to see to the enforcement of all ordinance provisions relating to
buildings or zoning and to inspect all buildings and structures being erected or altered, as frequently as may be necessary to insure
compliance with the Village ordinances. He shall be subject to the direction and supervision of the Director of Public Services.
(1965 Code, sec. 5-5.02)
B. Stop Orders: The Building Commissioner shall have the power to order all work stopped on construction or alteration or repair of
buildings, plumbing or electrical installations in the Village, when such work is being done in violation of any provision of any
ordinance relating thereto. Work shall not be resumed after the issuance of such an oral or written order, except on the written
permission of the Building Commissioner; provided, that if a stop order is an oral one, it shall be followed by a written stop order
within twenty four (24) hours. Such written stop order may be served by any police officer of the Village. (4-18-67)
C. Entry Powers: The Building Commissioner shall have the power to make or cause to be made an entry into any building or premises
where the work of altering, repairing or constructing any building or structure is going on, for the purpose of making inspections, at
any reasonable hour. (1965 Code, sec. 5-5.04)
D. Copies of Permit to Assessor: In addition to all other duties, the Building Commissioner shall forward to the Township Assessor and
County Assessor a copy of each building permit issued for buildings in Cook County, within fifteen (15) days of such issuance. Each
copy shall show the legal description of the lot or area concerned, and the real estate index number, if any, as required by Statute.
(1965 Code, sec. 5-5.05)
E. Enforcement Powers: The Building Commissioner is hereby empowered to cite and enforce any chapter and/or section of the
Municipal Code of the Village. (6-5-79)
1-9D-3: RECORDS AND REPORTS:
The Building Commissioner shall keep records of all applications and shall show the disposal thereof. He shall make monthly reports
to the Village Manager of his activities. (1965 Code, sec. 5-5.06)
ARTICLE E. PLUMBING INSPECTOR
1-9E-1: CREATION OF OFFICE:
There is hereby created the position of Plumbing Inspector. The Plumbing Inspector shall be appointed by the Village Manager. (1965
Code, sec. 5-6.01)
1-9E-2: GENERAL POWERS AND DUTIES:
A. Enforcement: It shall be the duty of the Plumbing Inspector and he is hereby empowered to enforce all Village ordinances relating to
the installation, care and standards of plumbing. He shall make all necessary inspections and tests which may be needed in the
performance of his duties. He shall be subject to the direction and supervision of the Director of Public Services. (1965 Code, sec.
5-6.02)
B. Stop Orders: Whenever the Plumbing Inspector shall find plumbing work being done in violation of the Village ordinances, he shall
have the power to order the work stopped until the ordinances are complied with. It shall be unlawful to continue any such work
after a stop order has been issued, except upon written order of the Village President or of the Plumbing Inspector; provided, that
when such a stop order is an oral order, it shall be followed by a written stop order within twenty four (24) hours. (1965 Code, sec.
5-6.03)
C. Entry Powers: The Plumbing Inspector shall have the power to enter any building or premises on or in which plumbing fixtures or
pipes are being installed, altered or repaired, at all reasonable hours, to make inspections to insure compliance with the ordinances
of the Village relative thereto. (1965 Code, sec. 5-6.04)
1-9E-3: RECORDS AND REPORTS:
The Plumbing Inspector shall keep records of all applications and shall show the disposal thereof. He shall make monthly reports to
the Village Manager of his activities. (1965 Code, sec. 5-6.05)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=967 67/605
ARTICLE F. ELECTRICAL INSPECTOR
1-9F-1: CREATION OF OFFICE:
There is hereby created the position of Electrical Inspector, who shall be appointed by the Village Manager.
1-9F-2: GENERAL POWERS AND DUTIES:
A. General: The Electrical Inspector shall have the right during reasonable hours to enter any building in the discharge of his official
duties, or for the purpose of making an inspection or test of the electrical equipment therein; and he shall have the authority to
enforce all the ordinance provisions relating to the electrical wiring and equipment. He shall have the power to cause the current in
any wire or conduit to be turned off whenever this is necessary in an emergency for the protection of life and property. He shall be
subject to the direction and supervision of the Director of Public Services.
B. Inspections: He shall make all inspections necessary to see to the enforcement of the Village ordinances; and no electric wiring
shall be covered until it has been inspected and approved.
C. Certificates: The Electrical Inspector shall give a certificate of approval to the owner or person in charge of premises which he has
inspected where he finds that the electrical apparatus and wiring therein fully comply with the ordinances of the Village.
D. Stop Orders: The Electrical Inspector shall have the power to order all work stopped on construction or alteration or repair of
buildings in the Village when such work is being done in violation of any provision of any ordinance relating thereto, or in violation of
the zoning ordinance. Work shall not be resumed after the issuance of such an order except upon the written permission of the
Inspector; provided, that if the stop order is an oral one, it shall be followed by a written order within twenty four (24) hours. Such
written stop order may be served by any police officer.
1-9F-3: RECORDS AND REPORTS:
The Electrical Inspector shall keep records of all applications and shall show the disposal thereof. He shall make monthly reports to the
Village Manager of his activities. (12-21-76)
Chapter 10
VILLAGE ELECTIONS
1-10-1: STATE LAW TO GOVERN:
Elections for Municipal offices shall be held as provided by statute, and at the time prescribed by statute1. (1965 Code, sec. 9-3.05, 9-
8.06)
1-10-2: JUDGES AND POLLING PLACES:
(Rep. by Ord., 7-19-1988)
1-10-3: ELECTION SUPPLIES:
(Rep. by Ord., 7-19-1988)
1-10-4: CONTESTING ELECTIONS:
A. General: The election of any Trustee may be contested by any elector of the Village, and the proceedings shall be in accordance
with the general laws of the State regulating the mode of contesting the elections of county officers, so far as the same may be
applicable. The contest of the election of Village President or other elected officers of the Village (other than Trustees) shall be in
accordance with the statutes relating thereto2. (1965 Code, sec. 9-3.06)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=967 68/605
B. Tribunal: The Board of Trustees shall be the tribunal before which such contest shall be heard, and their decision shall be final.
(1965 Code, sec. 9-3.07)
C. Contestant's Statement: When any person shall desire to contest the rights of another to hold office of Trustee to which said person
claims the right, he shall, within ten (10) days after the canvass of the votes of said election, file with the Village Clerk a statement
in writing briefly setting forth the points on which he will contest the election, which statement shall be verified by the affidavit of the
contestant. (1965 Code, sec. 9-3.08)
D. Service On Incumbent: Upon filing such statement, said contestant shall also serve a copy thereof upon the person whose election
he intends to contest (termed herein the respondent), and in case he is absent, or cannot be found, then by leaving a copy of said
statement at the respondent's usual place of residence. (1965 Code, sec. 9-3.09)
E. Hearing Witnesses: Whenever said statement shall have been filed and served as aforesaid, it shall be the duty of the Village
President and Board of Trustees, upon the application of either party, to fix the time and place for hearing witnesses and continue
the same from day to day thereafter, until all the testimony shall have been taken. (1965 Code, sec. 9-3.10)
F. Proof Confined To Statement: No testimony shall be taken or produced on the hearing before the Board of Trustees, except upon
the points set forth in the said statement required to be filed with the Village Clerk and served upon the respondent. (1965 Code,
sec. 9-3.11)
G. Decision: When all the evidence shall have been heard or taken, the Board of Trustees shall decide the same according to the right
of the matter, and shall declare as elected the person who shall appear by the evidence to have been elected. (1965 Code, sec. 9-
3.12)
H. Counting Ballots Of Contested Election: In all cases of contested elections, the parties shall have the right to have the package or
packages of ballots which have been returned to the Village Clerk, as required by law, opened in open session of the Board of
Trustees and then and there counted by a committee of three (3) Trustees appointed for that purpose by the Board of Trustees.
(1965 Code, sec. 9-3.14)
1-10-5: INELIGIBILITY; SPECIAL ELECTION:
Whenever it shall appear in any case that the person receiving the highest number of votes is ineligible to the office because of any
legal disqualification, it shall, for that reason, be the duty of the Board of Trustees to declare said election null and void, and
immediately call a special election to fill said office. (1965 Code, sec. 9-3.13)
Chapter 11
VILLAGE FINANCES
1-11-1: APPROPRIATIONS1:
During the first quarter of each fiscal year, as required by statute, the village president and board of trustees shall enact an
appropriation ordinance in which shall be itemized all anticipated expenditures to be met during the coming year, other than those
payable from bond issues.
This chapter shall be published as required by law within ten (10) days after its enactment. (1965 Code § 9-2.01)
1-11-2: TAX LEVY2:
No sooner than ten (10) days after the publication of the appropriation ordinance a tax levy ordinance shall be enacted as required by
law, levying such taxes as may be needed to meet the anticipated expenses of the coming year, together with such taxes as may be
required to meet outstanding bond issues, or for purposes payable from special taxes properly authorized.
A certified copy of the tax levy ordinance shall be filed with the county clerks in both Cook and DuPage Counties not later than the
second Tuesday in September. Such ordinance shall show the total appropriated for each item and the amount of tax levied therefor.
(1965 Code § 9-2.02)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=967 69/605
1-11-3: INDEBTEDNESS:
No indebtedness shall be incurred, excepting such indebtedness as may be payable solely from the proceeds of a duly authorized
bond issue from a designated specified source, unless there is a prior appropriation out of which such indebtedness could be paid, as
provided by statute. Provided, that during the first quarter of any fiscal year, before the enactment of the current appropriation
ordinance, the village may operate under the appropriation ordinance of the preceding year. (1965 Code § 9-2.03)
1-11-4: CONTRACTS; PURCHASES:
A. Procedure For Purchases Not Exceeding One Thousand Dollars: Unless otherwise specifically provided by law, ordinance or
resolution, no officer or employee of the village shall have authority to purchase supplies, materials or equipment on the village's
account except upon a requisition submitted by the head of the department for which said purchase or expenditure shall be made,
and in conformance with the village's purchasing policy manual.
B. Procedure For Contracts And For Purchases Exceeding One Thousand Dollars But Not Exceeding Twenty Thousand Dollars:
1. Purchases Between One Thousand Dollars And Five Thousand Dollars: Department heads may, with the approval and signature
of the finance director, purchase supplies, materials or equipment where the cost exceeds one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) but
does not exceed five thousand dollars ($5,000.00).
2. Purchases, Contracts And Public Improvements Between Five Thousand Dollars And Twenty Thousand Dollars: The village
manager may, in his or her discretion, without previous authorization of the board of trustees, purchase supplies, materials or
equipment where the cost exceeds five thousand dollars ($5,000.00), but does not exceed twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00),
and may enter into contracts for any services, work or public improvements where the cost does not exceed twenty thousand
dollars ($20,000.00).
3. Lowest Responsible Bidder: In the absence of special circumstances, the contract entered into or purchase made by the village
shall be given to the lowest responsible bidder based on proposals or bids solicited from appropriate open market sources for the
item to be purchased or contractual work to be performed. If the village is unable to obtain three (3) informal bids because the
item is a "single source item", the village manager may authorize the contract or purchase subject to this section without the
necessity of three (3) informal bids when the village manager deems it in the best interest of the village to do so.
4. Joint Purchase With Other Governmental Agencies: The village manager is authorized to participate in joint purchasing with
other governmental agencies pursuant to the governmental joint purchasing act3, when the village manager deems that it is in
the best interest of the village to do so.
C. Procedures For Contracts And Purchases Exceeding Twenty Thousand Dollars: All purchases of supplies, materials or equipment
where the cost exceeds twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00), and all contracts for services, work or public improvements where
the cost exceeds twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00), shall be let to the lowest responsible bidder after advertisement for bids in
conformance with the village's purchasing policy manual approved by the board of trustees and maintained by the village's finance
department, unless one of the exceptions to competitive bidding set forth in subsection D of this section exists.
D. Exceptions To Competitive Bid Requirements: The following are exempt from the bidding requirements set forth in subsection C of
this section:
1. All purchases of supplies, materials or equipment where the cost exceeds twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00), and contracts
for services, work or public improvements where the cost exceeds twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00), if authorized by a vote
of two-thirds (2/3) of all the trustees then holding office;
2. All contracts with firms or individuals covered under the local government professional services selection act4 , including
contracts for architectural, engineering and land surveying services, shall be governed by the statutory requirements set forth in
said act;
3. Joint purchases with other governmental agencies pursuant to the governmental joint purchasing act5;
4. Every contract for any work or public improvement to be paid for, in whole or in part by special assessment or special taxation,
which contracts shall be subject to the applicable statutory requirements;
5. All contracts providing the normal utilities to the various village activities;
6. All contracts awarded in accordance with state statutes where such statutes provide for or authorize conflicting or different
bidding procedures or requirements.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=967 70/605
E. Emergency Purchases: In case of an emergency arising from unforeseen causes which requires the immediate need to purchase
supplies, materials or equipment, or contractual services, work or public improvements as are necessary to protect life, the public
health and safety, and public property, the village manager or their designee may, when such action is in the best interests of the
public, secure on the open market at the lowest obtainable price any supplies, materials or equipment, or contractual services, work
or public improvements costing more than twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00) and place an order therefor. Every such purchase
or contract, whether oral or written shall be deemed to include a provision that it can be terminated at will and without cause on
twenty four (24) hours' written notice by the village without the village incurring any liability beyond that incurred for work done or
supplies or services delivered as of the time of termination. Documentation of the emergency and the need for immediate action will
be presented to the board of trustees in a reasonable period of time, but no later than the next regularly scheduled village board
meeting.
F. Contractor Bonds Required; Insurance: No contract shall be executed for public work of any kind, where the expense shall exceed
twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00), until the bidder submits to the village a performance or payment bond with a surety company
duly authorized to transact business in the state as surety thereon, in such form and for the full amount of the contract sum or price
in order to ensure the faithful performance of the contract and an observance of all ordinances of the village relating thereto. Said
bond shall conform to the requirements of sections 1 and 2 of the public construction bond act6 where applicable. In addition, the
village shall be named as an additional insured on the contractor's comprehensive liability policy or such other insurance as the
bidding documents may require. The village manager shall have the authority to require performance bonds before allowing the
village to enter into any contract other than for public works in such an amount as he or she shall find reasonable and necessary to
protect the best interests of the village.
G. Pecuniary Interests In Contracts: No village officers shall have any interest in any contract, purchase, work or business of the village
that is prohibited by section 3 of the public officer prohibited activities act7 and section 3.1-55-10 of the Illinois municipal code8.
H. Contractor Liable For Damages: In all cases in which any person shall perform any work either under contract with the village or by
virtue of any permission from the village, such person shall be liable to the village for any and every loss or damage that the village
may sustain, and for all sums it may have to pay to any person by reason of any loss or injury sustained in the consequence of any
carelessness or negligence in doing the work or by reason of any neglect or failure to comply with any provisions of any ordinance
of the village or otherwise. This subsection shall apply to all work done for the village, whether expressly so stated in a written
contract or not; and the acceptance of any contract or performance of any such work shall be construed as an agreement by the
person executing such contract or doing such work to be bound by and to become liable under this subsection. (Ord. O2014-18, 5-
20-2014)
1-11-5: RESERVED:
(Ord. O99-36, 8-17-1999)
1-11-6: BILLS; PAYROLL:
All bills payable by the village, other than for the payment of salaries established by the president and board of trustees, shall be
submitted to the president and board of trustees for approval before payment. (1965 Code § 9-2.05)
1-11-7: PAYMENT OF MONIES BY TREASURER:
The treasurer shall pay out money in payment of all bills, or for salaries, or for any other purpose other than the retirement of principal
or interest on bonds or tax anticipation warrants only upon warrant signed by the village president and the village clerk as provided by
statute. Such warrants shall designate the items to be paid and the funds from which they are to be paid. (1965 Code § 9-2.06)
1-11-8: AUDIT9:
As soon as practicable at the close of each fiscal year, and no later than six (6) months thereafter, there shall be an audit of all
accounts of the village made by a competent person authorized to act as an auditor under the laws of Illinois, to be designated by the
village board. Copies of such audit report shall be filed with the village clerk and with the director of the state department of revenue
and in such other places as may be required by law. (1965 Code § 9-2.07)
1-11-9: SALES OF VILLAGE PROPERTY:
In any sales of village property for a purchase price in excess of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), no goods shall be delivered to the
purchaser until payment has been received in full by the village by certified or cashier's check. (Ord., 12-4-1979)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=967 71/605
1-11-10: NONSUFFICIENT FUNDS CHECKS ILLEGAL; FEE:
No person shall tender to the village any check or other instrument of payment for which there are nonsufficient funds for payment on
such check or other instrument. Any person who tenders such a check or other instrument shall be assessed a fee for administrative
expense incurred by the village of twenty dollars ($20.00) for each such check or other instrument. (Ord., 12-14-1993)
