5-1-2: POLICE CHIEF; OFFICE CREATED:
There is hereby created the office of police chief. The police chief shall be appointed by the village president and confirmed by the
board of trustees upon the recommendation of the village manager. The police chief shall serve until such time as he or she resigns or
is removed or discharged from office by the village manager; provided, however, that the village manager shall provide to the board of
trustees a statement of reasons for removal or discharge, and provided further that no such removal or discharge shall become
effective unless confirmed by a majority vote of the village president and board of trustees. (Ord., 12-16-1991)
5-1-3: POLICE CHIEF; COMPENSATION:
The fixed salary of the police chief shall be approved and fixed by the village president and board of trustees upon the
recommendation of the village manager. (Ord., 12-16-1991)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=967 169/605
5-1-4: POLICE CHIEF; POWERS AND DUTIES:
The police chief shall be in command of the police department and shall be subject to the supervision of the village manager. The
police chief shall be responsible for the daily operation and routine assignment of the police department. The police chief shall be
responsible for the performance by the police department of all its functions, and all members of the police department shall serve
subject to the orders of the police chief. The specific powers and duties of the police chief shall include, but not be limited to, the
following:
A. Assigning duties to members of the police department;
B. Appointing a deputy police chief; (Ord. O2000-12, 5-2-2000)
C. Serving as custodian of and maintaining in good condition all property and equipment belonging to the police department;
D. Promulgating departmental rules and regulations in accordance with standard village procedures necessary to properly carry out
the functions of the police department; provided, however, that such rules and regulations shall not take effect unless approved by
the village manager;
E. Keeping or causing to be kept a record of all accidents and of any other emergency assistance rendered by the police department,
including the names of police officers in attendance;
F. Preparing a record of all criminal activity occurring within the village and of the disposition thereof;
G. Serving warrants, summons, and other process;
H. Serving as keeper of the village jail, having custody of all persons incarcerated therein, and preparing a record of persons arrested
or committed to the village jail;
I. Serving as custodian of all lost, abandoned, stolen, or lawfully seized property and preparing a record describing such property and
the date and circumstances of its delivery to the police department;
J. Preparing a record of the expenses of the police department;
K. Preparing a record of all meetings of the police department;
L. Enforcing all federal, state, and local laws to the extent of the village's jurisdiction to do so; and
M. Investigating all criminal activity occurring within the village. (Ord., 12-16-1991; amd. Ord. O2000-12, 5-2-2000)
5-1-4-1: DEPUTY CHIEF:
There is hereby created two (2) positions of deputy chief of police. Deputy chiefs may be appointed by the chief of police from time to
time. There shall be no more than two (2) deputy chiefs at any time. A deputy chief may be appointed from any rank of sworn, full time
officers of the police department, provided that no police officer shall be appointed as a deputy chief unless that officer has at least five
(5) years of full time service as a police officer in the Hinsdale police department. The position of deputy chief shall be an exempt rank
immediately below that of the chief of police. Deputy chiefs shall serve at the will and discretion of the chief of police. If a deputy chief
is removed from that position, then that officer shall revert to the rank held by that officer immediately prior to appointment to the
position of deputy chief. (Ord. O2003-48, 10-7-2003)
5-1-5: APPOINTMENTS, PROMOTIONS AND DISCHARGES:
Appointments to and promotions within the police department, other than to the office of police chief and deputy police chief, shall be
made by the board of fire and police commissioners in the manner provided by state law. No nonprobationary police officer shall be
discharged except after a hearing on charges before the board of fire and police commissioners as provided by state law. The board of
fire and police commissioners may discharge probationary police officers at any time without prior notice or hearing pursuant to such
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=967 170/605
rules and procedures, if any, as may be adopted by said board for such cases. Nothing in this section shall be construed as affecting
the power of the village president to appoint and village manager to remove or discharge the police chief pursuant to section 5-1-2 of
this chapter or the power of the police chief to appoint and remove the deputy police chief pursuant to section 5-1-4-1 of this chapter.
(Ord. O2000-12, 5-2-2000)
5-1-6: OATH:
The police chief and all police officers shall, before entering upon their duties, take and subscribe an oath to faithfully and impartially
discharge the duties of their positions. (Ord., 12-16-1991)
5-1-7: POWERS AND DUTIES OF POLICE OFFICERS GENERALLY:
It shall be the duty of all police officers to enforce all of the provisions of this code and other ordinances of the village and all statutes
and laws effective in the village; to preserve order and prevent infractions of the law and to arrest violators thereof; to mitigate the
results of, and to render aid in the case of accident or disaster; and to perform such other duties in the preservation of life and property
as may be assigned.
All police officers shall be conservators of the peace and shall have the powers specified in 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3-9-4.
All police officers shall be authorized to serve warrants, summons, and other process.
All police officers shall have the responsibilities, authority, and liability prescribed by statute, this code, and other village ordinances for
police officers. Nothing in this chapter shall be construed as creating any duty to any specific member of the public. (Ord., 12-16-1991)
5-1-8: REPORTING ACCIDENTS, DISTURBANCES AND REQUESTS FOR AID:
Whenever any accident, disturbance, or request for aid shall occur within the village, police officers at the scene shall make a written
report to the police chief, including all relevant information and as much of the following detail as may be applicable:
A. The place, day, time, and nature of the incident;
B. Weather conditions and lighting at the scene of any accident, including whether streetlights were lit;
C. The name and residence of any person injured and the nature and extent of the injury suffered;
D. The names and residences of principal witnesses; and
E. The name and residence of any attending physician. (Ord., 12-16-1991)
5-1-9: REGULATING TRAFFIC:
Police officers shall regulate and direct the travel and movement of persons and vehicles on the public streets and thoroughfares when
necessary to preserve the public order and minimize danger to persons or property. (Ord., 12-16-1991)
5-1-10: RENDERING ASSISTANCE TO FIRE DEPARTMENT:
Police officers shall aid the fire department in the event of fire by clearing the streets or grounds in the immediate vicinity so that
firefighters are not hindered in the performance of their duties. (Ord., 12-16-1991)
5-1-11: DELIVERING SEIZED OR FOUND PROPERTY TO POLICE CHIEF:
Police officers shall report and deliver all property seized or found by them to the police chief immediately after such property shall
come into their possession. (Ord., 12-16-1991)
5-1-12: ACCEPTING GIFTS PROHIBITED:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=967 171/605
No police officer shall accept any gift or emolument for his or her police services. (Ord., 12-16-1991)
5-1-13: APPEARING AS WITNESS:
Police officers shall appear as witnesses whenever necessary in a prosecution for violation of a federal or state statute or village
ordinance. No officer shall receive witness fees for such service in any action or proceeding to which the village is a party. (Ord., 12-
16-1991)
5-1-14: FURNISHING BAIL PROHIBITED:
No police officer shall become or furnish bail for any person arrested for a violation of a criminal law of the United States or the state or
of a village ordinance. (Ord., 12-16-1991)
5-1-15: WEARING BADGE:
Police officers shall wear a suitable badge to be furnished by the village. (Ord., 12-16-1991)
5-1-16: CONDUCT:
Police officers shall conduct themselves in a proper and law abiding manner and shall avoid the use of unnecessary force in the
execution of their duties. (Ord., 12-16-1991)
5-1-17: CARE AND RETURN OF VILLAGE ISSUED PROPERTY:
Any police officer who destroys his or her badge or any other property issued to him or her by the village shall be required to pay the
cost of replacing such item. Whenever any police officer shall leave, resign, be suspended, or be discharged, he or she shall
immediately deliver to the police chief the badge and all other property issued by the village. Any pay due or to become due such
members shall be withheld until such property is returned. (Ord., 12-16-1991)
5-1-18: DUTY OF PERSONS TO AID POLICE:
It shall be the duty of all persons when called upon by a police officer for assistance to promptly aid the officer in the discharge of his or
her duties. (Ord., 12-16-1991)
Chapter 2
CIVIL EMERGENCY
5-2-1: DEFINITIONS:
For purposes of this chapter, the following terms shall have the respective meanings:
ALCOHOLIC LIQUOR: Shall have the meaning set forth in section 3-3-3 of this code.
CURFEW: A prohibition declared by the village president pursuant to the provisions of this chapter against any person or persons
(except officials of any governmental authority and other persons expressly authorized by a governmental authority to act with respect
to a state of emergency) being upon any alley, street, public highway, parkway, sidewalk, park, playground, parking lot, other open
private property, or open private land adjacent to any of the foregoing within the hours specified by the village president in the
proclamation or declaration establishing such curfew.
FIREARMS AND FIREARM AMMUNITION: Shall have the respective meanings set forth in 430 Illinois Compiled Statutes 65/1.1, as
the same may from time to time be amended and in force.
FLAMMABLE LIQUID: Gasoline, kerosene, ether, or any other liquid which is flammable.
STATE OF EMERGENCY: Any riot, rout, affray, disorderly assembly, or unlawful assembly by three (3) or more persons which is
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=967 172/605
determined by the village president to be substantially characterized by the use of actual force or violence or by a clear and present
danger of the use of force and violence against persons or property in the village or by the clear and present danger of the use of force
or violence so as to interfere with the lawful and peaceable exercise of rights by persons within the village or the lawful and peaceable
use of property within the village, or any natural or manmade calamity within the village, such as, but not limited to, flood, fire, cyclone,
tornado, earthquake, or explosion, or the imminent danger thereof. (Ord. O2005-40, 8-16-2005)
5-2-2: DECLARATION OF STATE OF EMERGENCY:
Whenever the village president shall determine that a state of emergency exists in accordance with the standards of the definition set
forth in section 5-2-1 of this chapter, the village president shall have the extraordinary power and authority to exercise by executive
order all such powers of the corporate authorities and other officers of the village as may be reasonably necessary or appropriate to
eliminate or minimize the dangers arising from such state of emergency and for the protection of the health, safety, and general welfare
of the public; provided that, prior to exercising any such extraordinary power and authority, the village president shall have executed
under oath a written declaration of emergency containing the following:
A. A statement of certain facts known to the village president, either directly or on information and belief, that are believed by her or
him to constitute a state of emergency;
B. An express declaration of a state of emergency pursuant to this chapter;
C. Such further orders and directives as the village president may deem necessary or appropriate for the protection for the health,
safety, and general welfare of the public. (Ord. O2005-40, 8-16-2005)
5-2-3: PUBLICATION OF DECLARATION OF EMERGENCY:
As promptly as practicable under the execution by the village president of any declaration of emergency pursuant to the provisions of
this chapter, such declaration shall be filed with the village clerk and published by posting copies thereof at the following locations:
A. On the outside of the front door of the memorial building; and
B. On the outside of the front door of the village police station; and
C. On the outside of the front door of the United States post office in the village; and
D. At such other place or places within the village as the president may in his discretion direct.
In addition, the village president may direct that copies of such declaration of such emergency be delivered as soon as practicable
to any newspapers published or circulated within the village and to such radio, television, and other broadcasting stations either
within or without the village as may be reasonably necessary or appropriate to effect publication of such declaration of emergency
to persons within the village as promptly as practicable. Nothing contained in this section shall be a condition to any lawful arrest,
prosecution, or conviction of any person for a violation of any provisions of this chapter, provided that the village president shall not
have arbitrarily or capriciously failed or refused to make public a declaration of emergency in accordance with the provisions
hereof. (Ord. O2005-40, 8-16-2005)
5-2-4: CURFEW; REGULATION OF CERTAIN BUSINESSES:
Concurrently with the execution of a declaration of emergency under this chapter or at any time after such declaration but prior to the
expiration thereof, the village president may in her or his sole discretion and in the interest of public safety and welfare make any one
or more of all of the following orders:
A. Order the imposition of such curfew within certain hours specified by the village president in the order imposing such curfew;
B. Order the closing of any business holding a license for the sale of alcoholic liquor where such sales constitute the major part of the
business of the licensee;
C. Order the discontinuance of sale of alcoholic liquor by any person licensed for such sale under the applicable village ordinances;
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=967 173/605
D. Order the discontinuance of sale, distribution or giving away in any manner of any firearms, or firearm ammunition, or both;
E. Order such other safeguards and precautions as are, in the opinion of the mayor, necessary or appropriate for the protection of life
and property in the village and for the elimination of such state of emergency. (Ord. O2005-40, 8-16-2005)
5-2-5: EXPIRATION OF STATE OF EMERGENCY:
A state of emergency may be declared terminated at any time by the village president by a written declaration executed by the village
president and published in the manner provided for a declaration of emergency, and in any event a state of emergency shall expire
and terminate automatically without any further act by the village president not later than the adjournment of the first regular meeting of
the village board after execution of the declaration of emergency; provided, however, that the village board may from time to time
thereafter by motion extend such state of emergency and any orders issued by the village president in connection therewith until a time
fixed in such motion, but not later than: a) the adjournment of the next succeeding meeting of the village board, or b) forty eight (48)
hours after the time of such extension whichever shall occur first. (Ord. O2005-40, 8-16-2005)
5-2-6: VIOLATIONS:
Any person who violates the provisions of any curfew declared or order made by the village president pursuant to the provisions of this
chapter shall be guilty of a violation of this code and shall be subject to fine or imprisonment, or both, as provided. (Ord. O2005-40, 8-
16-2005)
5-2-7: EMERGENCY INTERIM SUCCESSION:
A. For the purposes of this section, the term "unavailable" means either that a vacancy in the office exists or that the lawful incumbent
of the office is absent or otherwise unable to exercise the powers and discharge the duties of the office.
B. In the event the village president is unavailable to exercise the powers and duties under this chapter, the powers of the office of
village president shall be exercised and duties shall be discharged by the designated emergency interim successors in the
following order:
1. President pro tem, if a president pro tem has been chosen pursuant to section 1-5-4 of this code.
2. Village board members by seniority based on the number of consecutive years in office. In the event two (2) or more village
board members have equivalent seniority, the village board member in such group who received the highest number of votes for
the current office at the most recent election at which such village board member participated. The village board member who is
designated the emergency interim successor pursuant to this subsection shall have the title "president pro tem".
C. The emergency interim successor shall exercise the powers and discharge the duties of the office of village president under this
chapter until such time as a vacancy which may exist shall be filled or until the officer of a preceding emergency interim successor
again becomes available to exercise the powers and discharge the duties of the office of village president. (Ord. O2008-01, 1-8-
2008)
5-2-8: SEVERABILITY:
The provisions of this chapter are intended to be severable, and if any provision, clause, or section of this chapter shall be held to be
invalid or unconstitutional for any reason, such invalidity or unconstitutionality shall not be deemed to invalidate or impair the
enforceability of the remaining provisions of this chapter to the extent that a reasonable construction and application thereof can be
effected. (Ord. O2005-40, 8-16-2005)
Chapter 3
MISDEMEANOR OFFENSES
5-3-1: GAMBLING:
A. It shall be unlawful to gamble or attend any gambling resort or to make a bet, lottery or gambling hazard, or to buy or sell any
chances or tickets in any gambling game, arrangement or device.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=967 174/605
B. It shall be unlawful to possess or expose for public use any slot machine, pinball machine or coin operated device designed for
gambling or any other gambling device, punchboard or paraphernalia with the intent to use the same for an unlawful purpose; and
any such device or paraphernalia kept with such intent may be confiscated by any member of the police department.
C. It shall be unlawful to maintain or patronize any establishment maintained for a gambling house or resort, anywhere in the village or
within one mile thereof.
D. It shall be unlawful to advertise any gambling house or resort in any street, alley or other public place within the village.
E. It shall be unlawful to maintain any video gaming terminal, as defined in section 5 of the video gaming act, 230 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 40/5, as amended, within the village corporate limits, and video gaming is prohibited within the village corporate limits. Any
video gaming terminal shall be immediately removed by the owner or operator of any public place or licensed establishment,
licensed fraternal establishment or licensed veterans' establishment, as defined in section 25 of the video gaming act, 230 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 40/25, as amended, in which it is located. (Ord. O2009-67, 12-15-2009)
5-3-2: DISORDERLY CONDUCT:
It shall be unlawful to commit disorderly conduct. A person commits disorderly conduct when he knowingly:
A. Does any act in such unreasonable manner as to alarm or disturb another and to provoke a breach of the peace; or
B. With intent to annoy another, makes a telephone call, whether or not conversation thereby ensues; or
C. Transmits in any manner to the fire department of any city, town, village or fire protection district a false alarm of fire, knowing at the
time of such transmission that there is no reasonable grounds for believing that such fire exists; or
D. Transmits in any manner to another a false alarm to the effect that a bomb or other explosive of any nature is concealed in such
place that its explosion would endanger human life, knowing at the time of such transmission that there is no reasonable grounds
for believing that such bomb or explosive is concealed in such place; or
E. Transmits in any manner to any peace officer, public officer or public employee a report to the effect that an offense has been
committed, knowing at the time of such transmission that there is no reasonable grounds for believing that such an offense has
been committed; or
F. Enters upon the property of another and for a lewd or unlawful purpose deliberately looks into a dwelling on the property through any
window or other opening in it; or
G. Transmits in any manner to the fire or police department of the village a request for an ambulance or other emergency service
knowing at the time of such transmission that there is no reasonable grounds for believing that the necessity for such a request
exists; or
H. Possesses in public view, or causes to be displayed in public view, an object that can reasonably be construed to be a firearm as
that term is defined in section 5-2-1 of this title. (Ord. O2007-57, 7-17-2007)
5-3-3: FIGHTING:
It shall be unlawful for any person to commit any assault or battery or to fight in the village. (1965 Code, sec. 28-1.07)
5-3-4: ASSEMBLAGES; DISTURBING, UNLAWFUL:
A. Disturbing Assemblages: It shall be unlawful for any person to disturb any lawful assemblage or gathering in the village. (1965
Code, sec. 28-1.08)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=967 175/605
B. Unlawful Assemblages: It shall be unlawful to collect, gather or be a member of any disorderly crowd, or any crowd gathered
together for any unlawful purpose. (1965 Code, sec. 28-1.14)
5-3-5: OFFENSES RELATING TO DRUGS:
A. Inhaling, Drinking Or Possessing Certain Substances: No person shall inhale, breathe, or drink, or possess with the intent to inhale,
any compound liquid or chemical containing toluol, hexane, trichloroethylene, acetone, toluene, ethyl acetate, methyl ethyl acetone,
trichloroethane, isopropanol, methyl isobutyl ketone, methyl cellosolve acetate, cyclohexanone, or any other substance for the
purpose of inducing symptoms of intoxication, elation, dizziness, paralysis, irrational behavior, or in any manner to change, distort
or disturb the audio, visual or mental processes. For the purpose of this section, any such condition so induced shall be deemed to
be an intoxicated condition. In addition, for the purpose of this section, the possession of any item altered so as to facilitate the
inhalation of such substance, or the possession of any other item or device designed to enable the inhalation of such substance
shall create a rebuttable presumption of intent to inhale said substance. The provisions of this subsection shall not apply to:
1. Any person who inhales, breathes or drinks such material or substances pursuant to the direction or prescription of any doctor,
physician, surgeon, dentist or podiatrist authorized to so direct or prescribe.
2. Any person who inhales, breathes, drinks or otherwise in any manner uses any narcotic, dangerous drug, or other material or
substance or combination thereof, which material or substance or combination thereof is defined by, and the use of which is
prohibited or regulated by any law of this state. (Ord., 4-1-1997; amd. Ord. O98-11, 4-7-1998)
B. Sale Of Certain Substances: No person shall knowingly sell or offer for sale, deliver or give away to any person any substances
containing any of the following volatile solvents, where the seller, offerer or deliverer knows or has reason to believe that the
substance will be used for the purpose of inducing symptoms of intoxication, elation, dizziness, paralysis, irrational behavior, or in
any manner to change, distort or disturb the audio, visual or mental processes: toluol, hexane, trichloroethylene, acetone, toluene,
ethyl acetate, methyl ethyl ketone, trichloroethane, isopropanol, methyl isobutyl ketone, methyl cellosolve acetate, cyclohexanone,
or any other substance which will induce symptoms of intoxication, elation, dizziness, paralysis, irrational behavior, or in any
manner change, distort or disturb the audio, visual or mental processes. (Ord., 11-1-1966; amd. Ord. O98-11, 4-7-1998)
C. Possession Of Cannabis:
1. Findings: The board of trustees is advised that there is a widespread illegal use of cannabis within the village and further finds
that the adoption of a local ordinance governing said illegal use of cannabis will be helpful for the effective control and elimination
of this drug.
2. Cannabis Defined: "Cannabis" includes marijuana, hashish and other substances which are identified as including any parts of
the plant Cannabis sativa, whether growing or not; the seeds thereof, the resin extracted from any part of such plant; and any
compound, manufacture, salt, derivative, mixture or preparation of such plant, its seeds, or resin, including tetrahydrocannabinol
(THC) and all other cannabinol derivatives, including its naturally occurring or synthetically produced ingredients, whether
produced directly or indirectly by extraction, or independently by means of chemical synthesis or by a combination of extraction
and chemical synthesis; but shall not include the mature stalks of such plant, fiber produced from such stalks, oil or cake made
from the seeds of such plant, and any compound, manufacture, salt, derivative, mixture or preparation of such mature stalks
(except the resin extracted therefrom), fiber, oil, cake, or the sterilized seed of such plant which is incapable of germination.
3. Possession Unlawful: It shall be a violation of this subsection for any person knowingly to possess any quantity of any substance
containing cannabis, except that the effect of this subsection shall be limited to persons knowingly possessing less than thirty
grams (30 g) of any substance containing cannabis. (Ord., 6-1-1976; amd. Ord. O98-11, 4-7-1998)
D. Responsibility Of Parents And Owners Of Residences:
1. It shall be unlawful for any parent or guardian to knowingly suffer or permit any person under nineteen (19) years of age, of which
he or she may be the parent or guardian, to violate any provision of this section. (Ord., 12-3-1982; amd. Ord. O98-11, 4-7-1998)
This section has been affected by a recently passed ordinance, 2019-08 - ALTERNATIVE NICOTINE PRODUCTS . Go to new
ordinance.
5-3-5.1: SALE OR DISTRIBUTION OF TOBACCO TO MINORS, BY MINORS OR AT INSTITUTIONS SERVING
MINORS:
A. Definitions:
MINOR: A person less than eighteen (18) years of age.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=967 176/605
TOBACCO PRODUCT: Any item, product or substance containing tobacco leaf, including, but not limited to, cigarettes, cigars,
snuff, pipe tobacco, chewing tobacco or dipping tobacco.
B. Sale To Minors: It shall be unlawful for any person, including, without limitation, any licensee, to sell, offer for sale, give away or
deliver any tobacco product to any minor; provided, however, that this subsection shall not be applied to prohibit a parent or legal
guardian of a minor from giving a tobacco product to that minor.
C. Sale By Minors: It shall be unlawful for any person to engage, employ or permit any minor to sell any tobacco product.
D. Purchase By Minors: It shall be unlawful for any minor to purchase any tobacco product, or for any minor to misrepresent his or her
identity or age, or use any false or altered identification, for the purpose of purchasing any tobacco product.
E. Possession By Minors: It shall be unlawful for any minor to possess any tobacco product; provided, however, that this subsection
shall not apply to a minor who, at the time of such possession of a tobacco product, is under the direct and immediate supervision
of that minor's parent or guardian or is in the house or residence of that minor's parent or guardian.
F. Sale Near Certain Institutions: It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, offer for sale, give away or deliver any tobacco product
within one hundred feet (100') of any public or private school or library or within one hundred feet (100') of any other building or
structure used for educational or recreational programs principally for minors. (Ord., 10-6-1992)
5-3-6: PUBLIC BATHING:
It shall be unlawful for any person to bathe at any public place or in any place open to the public view unless such person is
adequately garbed in a bathing suit. (Ord. O2002-65, 10-1-2002)
5-3-7: ADVERTISEMENTS:
A. Advertising: It shall be unlawful to advertise any unlawful business or article in the village and it shall be unlawful to injure or deface
any lawful advertisement or notice. (1965 Code, sec. 28-1.13)
B. Posting Bills: It shall be unlawful to post any bills or advertisements on any public property and it shall be unlawful to post any bill or
advertisement on any property without the written consent of the owner thereof. (1965 Code, sec. 28-1.17)
C. Medical Advertisements: It shall be unlawful for any person by himself, his agents or servants to distribute, cast, throw or place or
cause to be distributed, thrown, cast or placed in, upon or along any of the streets, alleys or other public places in the village, or
upon the porches or yards of private residences therein or within any dwelling or building in the village, any samples of
merchandise or medicinal preparations for the purpose or with the intent of advertising or making known in a general or
promiscuous manner any business, occupation, proposition, medical treatment, medicine or any other article whatsoever, or to
conduct any medicine show or entertainment to attract attention to any tonic, remedy, medicine or treatment for human ailments.
(1965 Code, sec. 28-1.19)
5-3-8: OFFENSES RELATING TO PROPERTY:
A. Injury To Public Property: It shall be unlawful for anyone to injure, deface or interfere with any property belonging to the village
without proper authority from the village president and board of trustees.
B. Missiles: It shall be unlawful to cast, throw or propel any missile on any street, alley or public place, and it shall be unlawful to throw
or deposit any glass, nails, tacks or other similar articles on any street, alley, sidewalk or other public place in the village.
C. Refuse: It shall be unlawful to permit or store any combustible refuse in such a way as to create a fire hazard or to store or throw
away any refuse of any kind on any street, alley or other public place.
D. Obstructing Stairways Or Exits: It shall be unlawful to obstruct or permit the obstruction of any stairway, aisle, corridor or exit in any
office building, factory, hotel, school, church, theater, assembly hall, lodge or other public hall, or any building used in part or wholly
for any such purpose, or in any building used by two (2) or more tenants or families in such manner that it interferes with the free
use of such stairway, aisle, corridor or exit.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=967 177/605
E. Scaffolds: Any scaffold or ladders placed in such a position that they overhang or can fall onto any public street, alley or other public
place in the village shall be firmly and properly constructed and safeguarded; and it shall be unlawful to place or leave any tools or
article on any such place in such a manner that the same can fall into any such street, sidewalk, alley or other public way from a
greater height than four feet (4').
F. Articles On Windows: It shall be unlawful to place any movable article on any window ledge, or other place abutting a public street,
alley or other place at a height above four feet (4') from the ground, in such a manner that the same can be or is in danger of falling
onto such sidewalk, street, alley or other public place.
G. Trespass: It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to commit a trespass within the village upon either public or private
property.
H. Specifically Enumerated Trespasses: Without constituting any limitation upon the provisions of subsection G of this section, any of
the following acts by any person, firm or corporation shall be deemed included among those that constitute trespasses in violation
of the provisions of subsection G of this section, and appropriate action may be taken hereunder at any time, from time to time, to
prevent and suppress any violation or violations of this section, the aforesaid acts being as follows:
1. An entry upon the premises, or any part thereof, of another including any public property, in violation of a notice posted or
exhibited at the main entrance to such premises or at any point of approach or entry or in violation of any notice, warning or
protest given orally or in writing by any owner or occupant thereof; or
2. The pursuit of a course of conduct or action incidental to the making of an entry upon the land of another in violation of a notice
posted or exhibited at the main entrance to such premises or at any point of approach or entry, or in violation of any notice,
warning or protest given orally or in writing by any owner or occupant thereof; or
3. A failure or refusal to depart from the premises of another in case of being requested, either orally or in writing, to leave by any
owner or occupant thereof; or
4. To wilfully harass, disrupt, interfere with or obstruct any public or governmental business or function being conducted within or
upon the premises or grounds of any public building; or
5. A failure or refusal by a person to depart from the premises or grounds of any public building owned or operated by the village in
case of being requested, either orally or in writing, to leave by an applicable village staff member, police officer or other
appropriate official due to a violation of the rules of conduct for public buildings, as amended, adopted by the board of trustees;
or
6. A failure or refusal by a person to depart from the premises or grounds of a public building owned and operated by any
governmental unit or body including, but not limited to, schools, libraries or governmental offices, when the continued presence of
the person shall injure or endanger the safety of said public building or unreasonably interfere with the administration thereof.
(Ord. O2011-59, 12-12-2011)
5-3-9: VANDALISM; PARENTAL RESPONSIBILITY:
A. Vandalism: It shall be unlawful for any person to wilfully destroy or injure any public or private property not his own.
B. Parental Responsibility:
1. Definitions: As used in this section, unless the context otherwise requires, the terms specified have the meanings ascribed to
them:
LEGAL GUARDIAN: A person appointed guardian, or given custody, of a minor by a circuit court of the state, but does not
include a person appointed guardian, or given custody of a minor under the juvenile court act1.
MINOR: A person who is above the age of eleven (11) years, but not yet nineteen (19) years of age.
2. Unemancipated Minor: The parent or legal guardian of an unemancipated minor residing with such parent or legal guardian shall
be presumed, in the absence of evidence to the contrary, to have failed to exercise proper parental responsibility and said minor
shall be deemed to have committed the acts described below with the knowledge and permission of the parent or guardian, in
violation of this section, upon the occurrence of the events described in subsections B2a, B2b and B2c of this section:
a. An unemancipated minor residing with said parent or legal guardian shall either be adjudicated to be in violation of any
ordinance, law or statute prohibiting wilful or malicious acts causing injury to a person or property, or shall have incurred
nonjudicial sanctions from another official agency resulting from an admission of guilt of violation of any ordinance, law or
statute prohibiting wilful and malicious acts causing injury to a person or property; and
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=967 178/605
b. Said parent or legal guardian shall have received a written notice thereof, either by certified or registered mail, return receipt
requested, or by personal service, with a certificate of personal service returned, from the police department of the village
following said adjudication or nonjudicial sanction; and
c. If at any time within one year following receipt of notice set forth in subsection B2b of this section, said minor is either
adjudicated to be in violation of any ordinance, law or statute as described in subsection B2a of this section, or shall have
incurred nonjudicial sanctions from another official agency resulting from an admission of guilt of violation of any ordinance,
law or statute as described in subsection B2a of this section. (Ord., 6-1-1976)
C. Penalty: Any person violating a provision of this section shall be fined not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) and not more
than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense. A separate offense shall be deemed committed for each piece of public or
private property destroyed or damaged and by each person who destroys or damages such property. Whenever the fine for an
offense under this section is in excess of two hundred dollars ($200.00), that fine shall be deemed to be reduced to two hundred
dollars ($200.00) in the event that service of summons as to that offense is made by certified mail, return receipt requested,
pursuant to 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-2-9.1. (Ord., 7-1-1986)
5-3-10: ABANDONED REFRIGERATORS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to abandon or keep any refrigerator, icebox or deep freeze in any place accessible to the public
without first removing the doors of such refrigerator, icebox or deep freeze. (1965 Code § 28-1.26)
5-3-11: OFFENSES RELATING TO WEAPONS:
A. Hunting: It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in killing or to hunt any bird or animal in the village. (1965 Code § 28-1.09)
B. Concealed Weapons: It shall be unlawful to carry any concealed weapons in the village without having first secured a license to
carry such concealed weapons issued under the laws of the state. (1965 Code § 28-1.10)
C. Discharge Of Firearms: It shall be unlawful to discharge any firearm or air gun in the village; provided, that this subsection shall not
be construed to prohibit any officer of the law to discharge a firearm in the performance of his duty; nor to any citizen to discharge a
firearm when lawfully defending his person or property. (1965 Code § 28-1.15)
5-3-12: NOISE CONTROL:
A. It shall be unlawful to produce or permit to be produced, whether on private or public property, any unreasonable noise to the
disturbance of the peace or quiet of any person residing in the vicinity. (Ord. O2008-63, 12-9-2008)
B. Under no circumstances shall outdoor amplified sound be allowed after ten o'clock (10:00) P.M. and before ten o'clock (10:00) A.M.
Sunday through Thursday and eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M. to ten o'clock (10:00) A.M. Friday and Saturday unless in conjunction
with a municipal or school district activity or event. (Ord. O2009-23, 4-7-2009)

the consent or invitation of the owner or occupant2. (1965 Code § 28-1.18)
5-3-14: OFFENSES REGARDING PUBLIC OFFICIALS:
A. Impersonation:
1. No person, other than a member of the Police Department shall assume to act as a policeman in any capacity within the Village.
(1965 Code, sec. 6-1.23)
No person shall impersonate any of the members of the Police Department, or shall maliciously or with intent to deceive, use or
imitate any of the signs, signals or devices adopted and used by the Police Department, or shall wear in public the uniform
adopted as the police uniform, after having been removed or suspended. (1965 Code, sec. 6-1.24)
2. No person shall impersonate without lawful authority any Village officer or employee. (1965 Code, sec. 9-1.12)

B. Interfering with Officers: No person shall interfere with or hinder any officer or employee of the Village while engaged in the duties of
his office or employment. (1965 Code, sec. 9-1.13)
C. Resisting Officer; Penalty: No person shall resist any policeman or constable, in the discharge of his duty, or shall in any manner
interfere with, hinder or prevent him from discharging his duty as such policeman or constable, or shall offer or attempt to do so. No
person shall in any way assist any person in custody of any policeman or constable to escape or to attempt to escape from such
