Chapter 5
PUBLIC LIBRARY
7-5-1: CARE OF LIBRARY BOOKS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to write upon, deface, tear, damage or fail to return any book belonging to, or in the possession or
under the control of the Board of Library Directors of the Village.1 (6-18-74)
Chapter 6
NEWSRACKS
7-6-1: DEFINITION:
The term "newsrack" shall mean, for the purposes of this chapter, any self-service or coin operated box, container, storage unit, or
other dispenser designed, intended, used, placed, installed, or maintained for the display and sale or distribution of newspapers,
periodicals, or other publications. (Ord. O2002-44, 7-16-2002)
7-6-2: CERTIFICATE OF COMPLIANCE REQUIRED:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=967 323/605
No person shall place, affix, erect, or construct, install, or maintain a newsrack on any public street, highway, sidewalk, parkway, alley,
or other public right of way without first obtaining a certificate of compliance therefor in accordance with the provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. O2002-44, 7-16-2002)
7-6-3: APPLICATION FOR CERTIFICATE:
An application for a certificate of compliance shall be filed with the village clerk and reviewed by the village engineer on a form
provided by the village therefor, and every application shall include the following information and materials:
A. The name, address, and telephone number of the applicant, who shall be the owner of, or principal in charge of, the newsrack(s);
and
B. The name, address, and telephone number of a responsible person whom the village may notify or contact at any time concerning
the newsrack(s); and
C. The number of newsracks and the proposed location of each newsrack, shown on a drawing provided by the village as part of the
application form; and
D. The type or brand of the newsrack(s), including an illustration and description of the newsrack and mount; and
E. A description of the newsrack(s), including height, width, and depth dimensions, color, lettering, decorative elements, operational
features, capacity, name and cost of the publication to be dispensed, and other features; and
F. A check in the amount of twenty five dollars ($25.00), pursuant to section 7-6-4 of this chapter; and
G. A check in the amount of ten dollars ($10.00) for each proposed newsrack, pursuant to section 7-6-5 of this chapter; and
H. All other information reasonably required by the village engineer to ascertain compliance with the provisions of this chapter. (Ord.
O2002-44, 7-16-2002)
7-6-4: CERTIFICATE OF COMPLIANCE FEE:
Every application shall be accompanied by a fee in the amount of twenty five dollars ($25.00) as payment of the costs of review,
inspection, and administration of the application. (Ord. O2002-44, 7-16-2002)
7-6-5: NEWSRACK INSPECTION AND MAINTENANCE FEE:
Every application shall be accompanied by a fee in the amount of ten dollars ($10.00) per newsrack as payment of the costs of review,
inspection, and administration of the newsracks. (Ord. O2002-44, 7-16-2002)
7-6-6: ISSUANCE OR DENIAL OF CERTIFICATE:
A. The village engineer shall issue, within five (5) business days after a properly completed application therefor, a certificate of
compliance for each newsrack that complies with all of the regulations provided in sections 7-6-7 and 7-6-8 of this chapter;
provided, however, that no certificate shall be issued until after payment of the required fees therefor.
B. The village engineer shall, within ten (10) business days, deny a certificate of compliance for any newsrack that does not comply
with any one or more of said regulations. (Ord. O2002-44, 7-16-2002)
7-6-7: MULTIPLE NEWSRACK AREAS:
A. The village may designate, from time to time, a certain area within the village as a multiple newsrack area. The following area is
hereby designated as a multiple newsrack area:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=967 324/605
1. That portion of the downtown area of the village bounded by Maple Street on the north, Garfield Avenue on the east, First Street
on the south, and Washington Street on the west is a multiple newsrack area.
B. The following additional areas may be designated by motion adopted by the board of trustees:
1. That portion of the village bounded by Railroad Avenue on the north, Stough Street on the east, Hinsdale Avenue on the south,
and Illinois Route 83 on the west is a multiple newsrack area; and
2. That portion of the village bounded by Hillgrove Avenue on the north, County Line Road extended on the east, Chicago Avenue
on the south, and Oak Street on the west is a multiple newsrack area.
C. No person shall place or maintain any newsrack within a multiple newsrack area except multiple newsracks placed and maintained
by the village. Such multiple newsracks shall be maintained for publications on request. Such multiple newsracks shall be subject
to the following standards:
1. The number of multiple newsracks in the multiple newsrack area shall be established by the village engineer, shall be sufficient in
number to accommodate all publications located in single newsracks as of July 1, 2002, and shall be reasonably sufficient to
accommodate general demand.
2. A publication shall be assigned a compartment upon application therefor by the publisher.
3. All publications with at least five (5) different daily editions each week shall be assigned a compartment in each multiple
newsrack. If the number of additional publications seeking placement exceeds available compartments, then a random selection
process shall be used to determine which publications shall be eligible for compartments.
4. Compartments shall be assigned randomly. For publications distributed on a paid basis, the assignments shall begin with the first
available top left compartment, proceeding downward and left to right. For publications not distributed on a paid basis, the
assignments shall begin with the top right compartment, proceeding downward and right to left.
5. Any compartment that remains empty for thirty (30) days or longer shall be deemed vacant and may be assigned to another
publication pursuant to this chapter. (Ord. O2002-44, 7-16-2002)
7-6-8: REGULATIONS APPLICABLE TO ALL NEWSRACKS:
A. Placement In Relation To Curb: No newsrack shall be placed closer than twenty four inches (24") to the edge of any curb. No
newsrack shall be placed further than thirty six inches (36") from the edge of any curb; provided, however, that the village engineer
may authorize and direct that a newsrack be placed near the wall of a building if the village engineer determines that public safety
considerations preclude placement of the newsrack near the curb at or near the location requested in the application. All newsracks
placed near the curb shall be placed parallel to, and facing away from, the curb. All newsracks placed near the wall of a building
shall be placed not further than six inches (6") from such wall.
B. Placement In Relation To Crosswalk: No newsrack shall be located within five feet (5') of any crosswalk or within ten feet (10') of
any intersection where no crosswalk is marked.
C. Placement In Relation To Emergency Facilities: No newsrack shall be located within ten feet (10') of any fire hydrant, fire call box,
police call box, or any other emergency facility.
D. Placement In Relation To Commuter Facilities: No newsrack shall be located within five feet (5') of any bus bench, plaza bench,
doorway to any commuter passenger station or any sign or other marking designating a bus stop.
E. Placement In Relation To Landscaped Areas: No newsrack shall be placed within two feet (2') of any area improved with lawn,
hedges, flowers, trees, or other landscaping elements.
F. Placement In Relation To Doorways: No newsrack shall be placed within five feet (5') of any doorway.
G. Placement In Relation To Windows: No newsrack shall be placed within three feet (3') of, or in any manner impeding the reasonable
view or use for display purposes of, any window.
H. Placement In Relation To Other Newsracks With Same Publication: No newsrack shall be placed within one hundred fifty feet (150')
of any other newsrack containing the same newspaper or news periodical.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=967 325/605
I. Placement In Relation To Other Newsrack Generally: No newsrack shall be placed facing another newsrack.
J. Placement In Relation To Poles, Parking Meters, Streetlights, Traffic Control Devices: No newsrack shall be placed within two feet
(2') of any utility pole, parking meter, streetlight, or traffic control sign or device.
K. Minimum Width Of Useable Passageway: No newsrack shall be placed in any location that reduces the width of a pedestrian
passageway to less than five feet (5').
L. Maintenance: All newsracks shall be maintained in a clean, freshly painted, smoothly operating, and orderly condition at all times. All
newsracks shall be kept free at all times of debris, litter, graffiti, bumper stickers, and other markings. Dirty newsracks shall be
promptly cleaned. Broken, dented, or poorly operating newsracks shall be promptly repaired or replaced.
M. Dimensions: No newsrack shall exceed the following dimensions:
1. Height: Thirty six inches (36") above the sidewalk or other surface on which it is placed, plus not more than thirteen inches (13")
for a coin slot.
2. Width: Twenty inches (20").
3. Depth: Twenty inches (20").
N. Card Holders: No newsrack shall include a card holder except only for the name of the publication to be dispensed from such
newsrack and announcements directly related to the content of such publication.
O. Advertisements Prohibited: Except as provided in subsection N of this section, no newsrack shall include or display any
advertisement of any goods, product, or service.
P. Private Newsracks Prohibited In Multiple Newsrack Area: No person shall place or maintain any newsrack in the multiple newsrack
area placed and maintained by the village. (Ord. O2002-44, 7-16-2002)
7-6-9: NONCONFORMING NEWSRACKS:
Within sixty (60) days after the effective date of this chapter, any newsrack that does not comply with any regulation of this chapter
shall be brought immediately into compliance, and thereafter all newsracks shall at all times be maintained in compliance, with all of
the regulations of this chapter or shall be removed. Any newsrack not so brought into, or maintained in, compliance or removed shall
be removed by the village engineer, subject to the provisions of section 7-6-11 of this chapter. (Ord. O2002-44, 7-16-2002)
7-6-10: NUISANCE DECLARED:
Any newsrack that is placed, affixed, erected, constructed, installed, or maintained on any public street, highway, sidewalk, parkway,
alley, or other public right of way in violation of any provision of this chapter is hereby declared a public nuisance and may be removed
at any time by the village engineer, subject to the provisions of section 7-6-11 of this chapter. (Ord. O2002-44, 7-16-2002)
7-6-11: NOTICE; REMOVAL FOR NONCOMPLIANCE:
If any newsrack is installed, used, or maintained in violation of the provisions of this chapter, then the village engineer shall give seven
(7) days' written notice of violation and an opportunity to cure such violation(s) to the person identified pursuant to subsection 7-6-3B of
this chapter. If any violation remains after the seven (7) day period has expired, then the newsrack may be removed immediately by
the village. If the owner of, or person responsible for, the newsrack is unknown, or if the placement of the newsrack creates a danger
to the public, then the village may summarily remove it and store it in any convenient place as provided herein. The village then shall
take reasonable steps to notify the owner of the newsrack. Upon failure of any owner to claim, within sixty (60) days, a newsrack that
has been removed and stored by the village, and to pay within said sixty (60) days the village's expenses for such removal and
storage, such newsrack shall be deemed to be unclaimed property in possession of the village and may be disposed of pursuant to
state law and village ordinances governing the disposition of unclaimed property. (Ord. O2002-44, 7-16-2002)
7-6-12: ABANDONED NEWSRACKS:
Any newsrack that, at any time, does not contain a current edition of the publication specified therefor for seventy two (72) consecutive
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=967 326/605
hours or longer, or that is empty at any time for seven (7) consecutive days or longer, shall be deemed abandoned, regardless of any
intent or purpose of the owner or operator thereof to use or not to abandon such newsrack. Every abandoned newsrack may be
removed immediately by the village engineer. (Ord. O2002-44, 7-16-2002)
7-6-13: PENALTY:
Any person who violates this chapter shall be subject to a fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) and not more than two hundred
dollars ($200.00) for each offense. Each day on which a violation occurs or continues shall be considered a separate offense. (Ord.
O2002-44, 7-16-2002)
Chapter 7
COMMERCIAL FILMING, PHOTOGRAPHY AND TAPING ACTIVITIES
7-7-1: PERMIT REQUIRED:
A. Application: The Village Manager may authorize the use of any street, right-of-way, or public building, equipment or personnel for
commercial uses in the filming, photography or taping of movies, television programs, commercials, or training films and related
activities. In conjunction with these uses, the Village Manager requires that any or all of the conditions and/or remunerations as
specified on the application be met as a prerequisite to that use. The application must be filed with the Village Manager within the
following time lines:
Feature films: Fourteen (14) days prior to filming.
Episodic television: Seven (7) days prior to filming.
Commercials/still photography: Three (3) days prior to filming.
The applicant shall agree, as part of the application, that the Village shall have full control over the use of public streets and
buildings of the Village while being used, as well as control over the hours of production and the general location of the production.
The Village reserves the full and absolute right to prohibit all filming or to order cessation of filming if determined to be detrimental
to the public health, safety, and welfare.
The applicant shall agree to allow the respective Village departments (i.e., Police, Fire, Building) to inspect all structures and/or
devices and equipment to be used in connection with the filming, photography and taping if required by the Village Manager.
B. Investigation: The Village Manager shall refer the application to the Police Department and to the Fire and Building Departments, as
deemed necessary, for investigation.
C. Time Limits On Activity: Filming and taping shall generally be allowed between the hours of seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. and eight
o'clock (8:00) P.M., Monday - Saturday, and nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. to six o'clock (6:00) P.M. Sundays and holidays. A request to
film or tape outside of these hours requires the written approval of the Village Manager. In addition, the Village Manager may
restrict or limit the time for filming, photographing or taping activities during rush-hour traffic or during periods when schools or
churches are in session within the affected area, or whenever, in his or her judgment, circumstances warrant such limitation. The
Village Manager and a representative of the applicant shall agree to a time daily past which no filming, photography or taping shall
occur. The applicant shall be fined at a rate established by the Village Manager for any filming, photography or taping that occurs
past the agreed upon time. Only one filming, photography or taping production shall be authorized in the Village on any given day.
The Village restricts the commercial filming of the exterior or interior of any single private residence to less than ten (10) days per
calendar year unless the express written permission of the Village Manager is given.
D. Report Of Vehicles And Equipment: The applicant shall provide a report listing the number of vehicles and types of equipment to be
used during the filming, photography or taping, including the proposed hours of use and the proposed parking locations. All such
parking locations shall be reviewed and approved by the Village Manager prior to their use. Every applicant shall pay the full daily
rate for every metered or permit parking space occupied by any vehicles and equipment. Equipment nonessential to actual filming
should be kept at a project base camp which will be determined in conjunction with the Village Manager's Office.
E. Village Control Over Public Streets, Buildings And Filming Activities: The Village shall have full and complete control over the use of
public streets and buildings of the Village while being used for filming, photographing or taping activities, as well as control over the
hours of production and the general location of the production. The Village reserves the full and absolute right to prohibit all filming,
photography or taping or to order cessation of filming, photography or taping if determined to be detrimental to the public health,
safety and welfare, and the applicant shall acknowledge its understanding and agreement of these Municipal powers as part of the
application.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=967 327/605
F. Termination Of Permit: Any permit issued herein may be terminated by the Village Manager in the event of a violation of any of the
conditions and requirements established by the Village Manager pursuant to this chapter, or of any traffic law or other Village
regulation, or of a deviation in the production schedule, number of vehicles, equipment location or any other information furnished
by the applicant with respect to the permit application.
G. Village Manager Designee: Any or all of the duties and functions of the Village Manager under this chapter may be performed by his
or her designee. (Ord. O2015-53, 12-8-2015)
7-7-2: GENERAL AND AUTOMOBILE LIABILITY INSURANCE REQUIRED:
The applicant shall furnish the Village Manager with a certificate of liability insurance naming the Village, its Corporate Authorities,
officers, officials, boards, commissions, employees, attorneys, agents and representatives as additional insureds with respect to any
and all claims which arise out of, or are in any way related to, the operations of the applicant within the Village in connection with the
particular commercial filming, photography or taping activity for which a permit is sought, in the general liability amount of one million
dollars ($1,000,000.00) for bodily injury or death to any person or for damage to any property from any occurrence arising out of or in
any way related to the applicant within the Village, and automobile liability, if applicable, in the amount of one million dollars
($1,000,000.00), including bodily injury and property damage. The applicant shall also submit to the Village Manager proof of the
appropriate workers' compensation and employer's liability insurance in force with respect to employees of the applicant. (Ord. O2015-
53, 12-8-2015)
7-7-3: HOLD HARMLESS AND INDEMNIFICATION AGREEMENT:
In addition to the insurance requirement, the applicant shall enter into a hold harmless and indemnification agreement, on a form as
provided by the Village Manager, to hold the Village and its Corporate Authorities, officers, officials, boards, commissions, employees,
attorneys, agents and representatives harmless, and to defend and indemnify the Village with respect to any loss, judgment, damages,
costs and expenses, settlement and compromises, claims and causes of action of every kind or nature, arising out of or in any way
related to the operations of the applicant within the Village in connection with the commercial filming, photography or taping activities
within the Village for which a permit is issued. (Ord. O2015-53, 12-8-2015)
7-7-4: FEES AND REMUNERATION FOR USE OF PUBLIC PROPERTY/PERSONNEL/EQUIPMENT:
The applicant shall pay the following permit fees and costs for use of public buildings and areas, and Village personnel, vehicles and
equipment. The fee for processing the permit provided in this section shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00) and shall be
nonrefundable. This fee is intended to cover the cost of Village personnel reviewing and processing the application.
Next, the following fees shall be a one-time, nonrefundable charge based on the type of production and the length of production. All
fees will be paid upfront before the production commences:
Still photography shoots $ 200.00
Filming productions lasting 5 days or fewer 500.00
Filming productions lasting more than 5 days and up to 14 days 1,000.00
Filming productions lasting more than 14 days An additional $75.00 per day fee
If special parking restrictions are necessary to accommodate the production, an additional fee of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) will
be charged to all permit holders.
In addition, the cost of use of police, public safety, public works or other Village personnel assigned to the permit activity (whether
requested by the applicant or not) shall be one and a half times the employee's hourly rate of pay. Examples of employee staff time
include traffic control and enforcement. The Village reserves the right to determine when use of Village personnel is required and
warranted. To the extent that the Village will be required to utilize Village vehicles and equipment, the Village will require
reimbursement for the hourly rate associated with each vehicle or piece of equipment.
Next, the rate for use of public property shall be determined by the Village Manager according to the extent of such use as follows: for
total or disruptive use of a public building during regular operating hours, eight hundred twenty five dollars ($825.00) per day plus
seventy dollars ($70.00) per hour for each hour or part thereof beyond regular operating hours; for partial, non-disruptive use of such
public building, five hundred ten dollars ($510.00) per day plus thirty five dollars ($35.00) per hour for each hour or part thereof beyond
regular operating hours; for total closure of a public street, park area or right-of-way, eighty dollars ($80.00) per hour; for partial closure
or obstruction of such public street, park area or right-of-way, forty dollars ($40.00) per hour. Applicant will be responsible for obtaining
permission from BNSF if filming, photography or taping on rail tracks is requested and for providing any required flagmen and/or road
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=967 328/605
signage. The Village Manager may waive part or all the fees for a nonprofit organization at his or her discretion. (Ord. O2015-53, 12-8-
2015)
7-7-5: NOTIFICATION; PRE-PRODUCTION MEETING:
The applicant shall be required to contact any or all property owner(s) and residents in the affected neighborhood as defined by
boundaries set by the Village Manager. The applicant shall write a short description of the proposed project along with the filming
schedule to distribute to the property owners or residents. The applicant shall provide a report attesting to such distribution and noting
any owner's or resident's reaction along with the addresses and phone numbers of all reacting property owners. This completed report
must be delivered to the Office of the Village Manager prior to approval for filming. The Village reserves the right to not allow filming,
photography or taping in any location where any of the property owners in the affected neighborhood file written objections to such
filming, photography or taping. The applicant may also be required to meet with Village staff at least forty eight (48) hours in advance
of the desired production date at the discretion of Village staff. (Ord. O2015-53, 12-8-2015)
7-7-6: SURETY BOND REQUIRED:
In addition to the foregoing requirements, the applicant shall, as a part of any application for commercial filming, photography or taping,
deposit with the Village Treasurer cash or a surety bond in the amount of fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000.00) as security for the
payment of any damage which may result to such public way, public park or public building by reason of the applicant's use of the
same pursuant to a permit to be issued herein. Any part of said deposit not needed or used to repair, replace or restore damage so
occasioned to public property by the applicant at the end of the permit period shall be returned to the applicant within ten (10) days
after the expiration date. The cash deposit or surety bond is required before a permit can be issued. (Ord. O2015-53, 12-8-2015)
7-7-7: VILLAGE RECOGNITION:
The Village shall be duly recognized in the publication of any film, tape, book or periodical, which includes therein public buildings or
public areas of the Village. (Ord. O2015-53, 12-8-2015)
Title 8
FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION
Chapter 1
FIRE DEPARTMENT
8-1-1: DEPARTMENT CREATED:
There is hereby created a fire department, an executive department of the village, which shall be under the jurisdiction of the village
manager. The fire department shall consist of the fire chief and such other officers, in such numbers, as may be authorized by the
village president and board of trustees from time to time, including deputy fire chiefs, captains, lieutenants, firefighter/EMT-Bs, and
firefighter/paramedics. (Ord. O2002-31, 5-21-2002)
8-1-2: FIRE CHIEF; OFFICE CREATED:
There is hereby created the office of fire chief. The fire chief shall be appointed by the village president and confirmed by the board of
trustees upon the recommendation of the village manager. The fire chief shall serve until such time as he or she resigns or is removed
or discharged from office by the village manager; provided, however, that the village manager shall provide to the board of trustees a
statement of reasons for removal or discharge, and provided further that no such removal or discharge shall become effective unless
confirmed by a majority vote of the village president and board of trustees. (Ord., 12-16-1991)
8-1-3: FIRE CHIEF; COMPENSATION:
The fixed salary of the fire chief shall be approved and fixed by the village president and board of trustees upon the recommendation
of the village manager. (Ord., 12-16-1991)
8-1-4: FIRE CHIEF; POWERS AND DUTIES:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=967 329/605
The fire chief shall be in command of the fire department and shall be subject to the supervision of the village manager. The fire chief
shall be responsible for the daily operation and routine management of the fire department. The fire chief shall be responsible for the
performance by the fire department of all its functions, and all members of the fire department shall serve subject to the orders of the
fire chief. The specific powers and duties of the fire chief shall include, but not be limited to, the following:
A. Assigning duties to members of the fire department;
B. Serving as custodian of and maintaining in good condition all property and equipment belonging to the fire department;
C. Promulgating departmental rules and regulations in accordance with standard village procedures necessary to properly carry out
the functions of the fire department; provided, however, that such rules and regulations shall not take effect unless approved by the
village manager;
D. Keeping or causing to be kept a record of all fires and of any other emergency assistance rendered by the fire department, including
the names of firefighters in attendance;
E. Preparing a record of the expenses of the fire department;
F. Preparing a record of all meetings of the fire department;
G. Entering the premises on which a fire has occurred, when necessary, to investigate and determine the cause, origin, and
circumstances of such fire; and
H. Appointing the deputy fire chief. (Ord. O2004-49, 10-5-2004)
8-1-4-1: DEPUTY FIRE CHIEF:
There is hereby created one position of deputy fire chief. The deputy chief may be appointed by the fire chief from time to time. There
shall be no more than one deputy chief at any time. A deputy chief may be appointed from any rank of sworn, full time officers of the
fire department, provided that no firefighter shall be appointed as a deputy chief unless that firefighter has at least five (5) years of full
time service as a firefighter in the Hinsdale fire department. The position of deputy chief shall be an exempt rank immediately below
that of the fire chief. The deputy chief shall serve at the will and discretion of the fire chief. If a deputy chief is removed from that
position, then that officer shall revert to the rank held by that officer immediately prior to appointment to the position of deputy chief.
(Ord. O2004-49, 10-5-2004)
8-1-5: APPOINTMENTS, PROMOTIONS AND DISCHARGES:
Appointments to and promotions within the fire department, other than to the offices of fire chief and deputy fire chief, shall be made by
the board of fire and police commissioners in the manner provided by state law. No nonprobationary firefighter shall be discharged
except after a hearing on charges before the board of fire and police commissioners as provided by law. The board of fire and police
commissioners may discharge probationary firefighters at any time without prior notice or hearing pursuant to such rules and
procedures, if any, as may be adopted by said board for such cases. Nothing in this section shall be construed as affecting the power
of the village president to appoint and village manager to remove or discharge the fire chief pursuant to section 8-1-2 of this chapter, or
the power of the fire chief to appoint and remove a deputy fire chief pursuant to section 8-1-4-1 of this chapter. (Ord. O2004-49, 10-5-
2004)
8-1-5-1: RESIDENCY:
Each full time member of the fire department shall reside within the greater Chicago metropolitan area, that is, within one of the
following counties: Cook, DuPage, Kane, Lake, McHenry, or Will. Any failure to comply with this residency requirement shall be
deemed cause for discharge from the service of the village, and any full time member who shall fail to comply may be discharged in
the manner provided by law. A full time member shall have one year after completion of her or his probationary period within which to
comply with this residency requirement. (Ord. O2004-30, 6-1-2004)
8-1-6: POWERS AND DUTIES OF FIREFIGHTERS GENERALLY:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=967 330/605
It shall be the duty of all firefighters to prevent and extinguish accidental or destructive fires; to mitigate the results of, and to render aid
in the case of, accident or disaster and to perform such other duties in the preservation of life and property as may be assigned.
All firefighters shall have the responsibilities, authority, and liability prescribed by state statute, this code, and other village ordinances
for firefighters. Nothing in this chapter shall be construed as creating any duty to any specific member of the public. (Ord., 12-16-1991)
8-1-7: DIRECTING DEPARTMENT AT FIRES:
The fire chief or, in the absence of the fire chief, the firefighter of the highest rank in attendance shall take command at a fire and shall
direct the efforts of the fire department to extinguish the fire. (Ord., 12-16-1991)
8-1-8: REMOVING PROPERTY TO PREVENT SPREAD OF FIRE:
The fire chief, or in the absence of the fire chief, the firefighter in command at a fire may cause property to be removed and buildings to
be torn down or destroyed when necessary to prevent the spread of fire to other property. (Ord., 12-16-1991)
8-1-9: PAID ON CALL FIREFIGHTERS:
The fire chief with the advice and consent of the village manager may appoint paid on call firefighters up to such number as the board
of trustees shall from time to time deem necessary. Paid on call firefighters shall be members of the fire department when on duty. The
fire chief with the advice and consent of the village manager may revoke appointments at any time. Paid on call firefighters shall be
compensated for their services at such rate as the village president and board of trustees shall approve and fix. The village may
provide insurance to paid on call firefighters, to cover in line of duty accidents only, upon the recommendation of the village manager
with the approval of the village president and board of trustees. (Ord., 12-16-1991; amd. Ord., 11-1-1994)
8-1-10: CLAIMING PROPERTY SAVED FROM FIRE:
Only persons making satisfactory proof of ownership to the fire chief or, in the absence of the fire chief, the firefighter in command shall
be entitled to claim any property saved by the fire department from a fire. (Ord., 12-16-1991)
8-1-11: ENTERING FIRE DEPARTMENT PREMISES:
Only persons having business pertaining to the fire department or with authorization from personnel of the fire department shall enter
fire department premises or any place where the equipment and apparatus of the fire department is stored. (Ord., 12-16-1991)
8-1-12: USING FIRE APPARATUS:
Only persons with authorization from the fire chief or, in the absence of the fire chief, the firefighter in command shall remove any fire
engine, hose, or other apparatus from its place of deposit and use such for any private purpose. (Ord., 12-16-1991)
8-1-13: DRIVING OVER UNPROTECTED HOSE:
Only persons with authorization from the fire chief or, in the absence of the fire chief, the firefighter in command shall drive any
automobile, truck, or other vehicle over unprotected hose laid down by the fire department on any street or alley. (Ord., 12-16-1991)
8-1-14: OBSTRUCTING USE OF FIRE HYDRANT:
No person shall in any manner obstruct the use of any fire hydrant, or have or place any material in front of any fire hydrant. Any such
material found obstructing any fire hydrant may be removed by fire department personnel at the risk and expense of the owner or
claimant of such material. (Ord., 12-16-1991)
8-1-15: DUTIES OF PERSONS TO AID FIREFIGHTERS:
It shall be the duty of all persons when called upon by a firefighter for assistance to promptly aid the firefighter in the discharge of his or
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=967 331/605
her duties. (Ord., 12-16-1991)
8-1-16: BUILDING OR FIRE HAZARDS; DUTY TO REMEDY:
No owner, lessee, or other person having lawful possession or control of any premises, building, or other structure shall permit such
premises, building, or structure to become especially liable to fire, or to become liable to cause injury or damage by collapse or other
cause, or to endanger persons or property by reason of faulty construction, age, lack of proper repair, or any other cause. No owner,
lessee, or other person having lawful possession or control of any premises, building or other structure shall keep, maintain or allow to
be kept or maintained in or on such premises, building, or other structure combustible or explosive materials which may endanger the
safety of said premises, building or other structure or any person. (Ord., 12-16-1991)
Chapter 2
MUTUAL AID
(Rep. by Ord., 12-16-1991)
Chapter 3
FIRE PREVENTION CODE
(Rep. by Ord., 7-19-1988)
Chapter 4
FIREWORKS
8-4-1: FIREWORKS PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to offer for sale, expose for sale, sell at retail, use or explode any fireworks within the village. For the
purpose of this section, the term "fireworks" shall mean and include any explosive composition, or any substance or combination of
substances, or article prepared for the purpose of producing a visible or audible effect of a temporary exhibitional nature by explosion,
combustion, deflagration or detonation, and shall include blank cartridges, toy cannons, in which explosives are used, the type of
balloons which require fire underneath to propel the same, firecrackers, torpedoes, skyrockets, Roman candles, sparklers, bombs or
other fireworks of like construction and any fireworks containing any explosive compound, or any tablets or other device containing any
explosive substance, or containing combustible substances producing visual effects; provided, however, that the term "fireworks" shall
not include toy pistols, toy canes, toy guns or other devices in which paper or plastic caps containing twenty five-hundredths (0.25)
grain or less of explosive compound are used; provided, they are so constructed that the hand cannot come in contact with the cap
when in place for the explosion. The sale and use of toy pistol paper or plastic caps which contain less than twenty-hundredths (0.20)
grain of explosive mixture shall be permitted at all times. Notwithstanding the foregoing, the use and explosion of fireworks shall be
permitted when specifically authorized by the village board of trustees in connection with a village sponsored holiday event. All
permitted fireworks displays and/or pyrotechnic displays shall comply with the Illinois fireworks use act, 425 Illinois Compiled Statutes
35/0.01 et seq., as amended, and the Illinois pyrotechnic distributor and operator licensing act, 225 Illinois Compiled Statutes 227/1 et
seq., as amended, and any regulations promulgated by the office of the state fire marshal pursuant thereto. (Ord. O2006-40, 6-6-2006)
Chapter 5
PUBLIC ASSEMBLY HALLS
8-5-1: REGULATIONS:
It shall be unlawful to hold, manage or conduct any meeting or entertainment of any kind in the village, in any premises other than a
building constructed in full compliance with the village ordinances and laws pertaining thereto for auditorium, theater or lodge room
purposes, excepting in compliance with the provisions of this chapter. (1965 Code, sec. 27-3.01)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=967 332/605
8-5-2: INSPECTIONS:
No such gathering or entertainment shall be held or presented in any premises other than a building as described in the preceding
section, unless such premises have been examined by the building commissioner not more than three (3) days before the date of such
gathering and found to be free from any fire hazard and found to be suitable for the purpose. No structure enclosed by a roof shall be
used for such purpose unless the same is constructed of nonflammable materials. Provided that tents or structures covered by canvas
or similar materials may be so used if such canvas or other material has been properly treated so as to be rendered fire resistive.
(1965 Code, sec. 27-3.02)
8-5-3: PREMISES REQUIREMENTS:
A. Exits: Adequate unobstructed exits shall be provided in all premises used for such purposes to permit rapid egress of all persons
attending, and there shall be at least two (2) separate exits located at least thirty feet (30') from each other. (1965 Code, sec. 27-
3.03)
B. Seats: Any stand or rows of seats used in such premises shall be so constructed as to be safe for the use designated, and shall be
sufficiently strong to carry the same weight and stress as is required for the construction of the auditorium floors of theater
buildings, not less than one hundred (100) pounds per square foot.
It shall be unlawful to admit to any such premises a number of persons to exceed the number of actual seats maintained for their
accommodation. (1965 Code, sec. 27-3.04)
C. Doors: All doors or gates or exits from premises used for such purposes shall open outward and no such exit shall be so
constructed or locked that egress from inside the premises is blocked. (1965 Code, sec. 27-3.05)
8-5-4: NOTICE:
It shall be the duty of any person conducting, calling for or managing any gathering in any premises other than a theater, lodge room or
auditorium building constructed as provided in section 8-5-1 of this chapter, to notify the village clerk of the date of such intended use
at least ten (10) days before such meeting is to take place; upon such notice the building commissioner shall inspect the premises to
determine whether or not it complies with the provisions hereof. Any permit issued for any such gathering shall be subject to the
condition that this chapter is fully complied with, whether or not such condition is embodied in the permit. (1965 Code, sec. 27-3.06)
Title 9
BUILDING REGULATIONS
Chapter 1
ADMINISTRATIVE PROVISIONS
9-1-1: PERMITS REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to construct, enlarge, alter, or demolish a structure, or to change the occupancy of a building or structure in a
manner requiring greater strength, exitway, or sanitary provisions, or to change to another use, or to install or alter any equipment for
which provision is made in or the installation of which is regulated by this code, or to conduct land disturbing activities, or to conduct
paving or surfacing of the ground, or handle, process, or serve food or drink, without first filing an application with the building
commissioner in writing and obtaining the required permits therefor as required by this title; except that ordinary repairs, as defined in
the international building code hereinafter adopted by reference, shall be exempt from this provision. (Ord. O2008-55, 10-7-2008)
9-1-2: APPLICATIONS FOR PERMITS:
All applications for permits shall be made to the building commissioner and shall be accompanied by plans and specifications in
duplicate showing in detail the work to be done. Such plans shall be verified by the signature either of the owner of the premises or of
the architect or contractor in charge of operations.
If work for which a permit is required has already been undertaken before the building commissioner has approved a permit application
and issued a permit, then the applicant for such permit shall pay, in addition to the regular permit fee, a fee in the amount specified
under the reinspection fee schedule for such work.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=967 333/605
Every application for a permit shall certify that the proposed work shall be completed according to plans and specifications
accompanying the application within one year from the date such permit was issued. Failure to complete within that time period shall
constitute a violation of the building code. (Ord. O2008-46, 8-12-2008)
9-1-3: APPROVAL OF PLANS:
Upon receipt of a fully and properly completed application to determine whether the proposed work will comply with all codes and
ordinances applicable thereto, including, without limitation, the provisions of this title and of the zoning code. If upon review the building
commissioner determines that the application has not been fully and properly completed or that the proposed work would not comply
with one or more codes or ordinances applicable to such work, then the building commissioner shall not approve such application but
shall return such application and the plans submitted therewith to the applicant, with exceptions noted. If upon review, the building
commissioner determines that the application has been fully and properly completed, but that the application requires the approval of
the board of trustees or other board, commission or official, then the building commissioner shall forward the application to the
appropriate board, commission or official in the manner provided therefor. Upon the building commissioner's determination that the
proposed work would comply with all codes and ordinances applicable to such work, that the appropriate fee has been paid and that all
required approvals therefor have been obtained, the building commissioner shall approve such application and cause a permit to be
issued therefor. Upon issuance of a permit, one set of plans shall be returned by the building commissioner to the applicant. No permit
shall be issued except after approval of the application and plans and the payment of the fee provided herein. (Ord. O2008-46, 8-12-
2008)
This section has been affected by a recently passed ordinance, 2019-03 - PERMIT FEES . Go to new ordinance.
9-1-4: PERMIT FEES:
A. Plan Review And Administrative Filing Fee:
1. Outside Agency: Should a plan review be required to be performed by a third party, as determined by the village, all fees and
charges related to the performance of such plan review shall be paid by the permit applicant. The applicant shall pay an
additional twenty percent (20%) of the charges of the plan review performed by a third party for administrative costs and plan
review performed by village personnel. A deposit shall be submitted at the time of application based upon the anticipated total
review fee as determined by the village.
2. In House Plan Review Performed By Village Personnel: Plan review performed by village personnel shall be charged at a rate of
eighty dollars ($80.00) per hour, with a one hour minimum paid at the time of application.
3. Expedited Reviews: The village, or a third party as determined by the village, shall perform plan reviews on an expedited basis
for new construction, additions, and remodeling, if such expedited review is approved by the building commissioner based upon
a request by an applicant, at a rate of one and one-half (11/2) times the rates set forth in subsections A1 and A2 of this section.
4. Engineering Review And Inspection Fee: The plan review fee for the inspection of public and private site improvements for
nonresidential and multi-family developments shall be due upon submission of final engineering plans for such improvements.
The fee shall be one percent (1%) of the engineer's estimate of the cost of said improvements.
5. Tree Plan Review Fee: Tree plan review performed by the village arborist shall be one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) and shall
cover the costs of reviewing tree plans and associated site visits.
6. Fees Nonrefundable: The plan review fees set forth in this section are nonrefundable and shall be paid regardless of whether a
permit is ultimately issued.
B. Building Permit Fees:
1. New Structures: The building permit fee for new structures shall be one dollar ($1.00) per square foot of total floor area of the
proposed new structure, including basements, attics, and garages, up to and including twenty five thousand (25,000) square feet.
The fee shall be fifty cents ($0.50) for every square foot of total floor area thereafter.
2. Remodeling And Alterations: Where a building permit applicant proposes to add no new square footage, the building permit fee
shall be two percent (2%) of the value of construction. In no event shall the fee be less than one hundred dollars ($100.00). In
setting a fee based on the value of construction, the building commissioner may consider any of the following:
a. An estimate furnished by the permit applicant;
b. An affidavit from the owner or the owner's agent; or
c. A calculation to be made by the building commissioner based on the most recent edition of "RS Means Square Foot Costs"
book.
